title: Airdrop
description: Distributing tokens to a designated group of recipients based on certain qualifying criteria.
details:
An airdrop operates by disbursing tokens to the wallets of selected recipients, often without necessitating any proactive steps on their part. The criteria for selection may encompass a range of factors such as ownership of a specific token or engagement within a particular blockchain by a stipulated date. The airdrop is executed at a preset time, following which the tokens become accessible for the recipients to utilize or trade.
The underpinning theory for airdrops stems from marketing principles and network effect dynamics, aiming for wider token distribution and heightened engagement. By dispersing tokens, projects aspire to expand their user base and foster active participation. The mechanism also intertwines with game theory, where recipients, now vested with a stake, are incentivized to partake actively within the ecosystem.
Advantages & Applications
Marketing & User Engagement: Offers a catalyst for new users to interact with the project.
Loyalty: Can be used to reward existing users for participation, resulting in increased retention or loyalty.
Governance: May be used to bootstrap a project’s governance strategy by decentralizing voting tokens.
Liquidity Enhancement: Can spur trading activity as newly disseminated tokens enter circulation.
Limitations & Risks
Regulatory Scrutiny: Looming risk of being categorized as a security offering, subject to regulatory constraints.
Airdrop farming: Potential to draw in short-term speculators who exploit the mechanism by repeating certain tasks actions (often from multiple addresses) to boost the number of tokens they will receive.
Short-term sell pressure: Dropping large amounts of tokens to users all at once may cause a large spike in sell pressure if recipients do not have an incentive to hold the token, such as utility or expectation of future rewards.
Price manipulation: “Low float, high FDV” airdrops have been used to artificially inflate prices by giving a large percentage of the unlocked supply to professional market makers (see explanation).
Key Considerations
Target Criteria: Define selection criteria to align with your strategic goals.
Timing Strategy: A poorly timed airdrop could overlap with market events or network congestion, thereby impeding distribution.
Regulatory Compliance: Consult legal advice to navigate potential securities law implications.
Monitoring Impact: Track metrics like engagement and trading volume post-airdrop to gauge its effectiveness.
Push or Pull: Push is gas expensive and can send tokens to dormant addresses. Most projects opt for pull using Merkle root, cryptographic technique to verify eligibility, and allow users to claim their own allocation from the contract. This also prevents tokens from being sent to dormant addresses.
Type of Airdrop: Options include retroactive as in UNI, recurring as in OP, using an options strategy as in Tapioca, or conditional claim as in dYdX. Refer below for examples.
Vesting & Lock-ups: Consider combining airdrops with a vesting or lock-up scheme in order to mitigate short-term sell pressure and align recipients with the long-term success of the project. See SAFE example.
This entry was coauthored by Alex Weseley.

example_details:
Uniswap pioneered the use of airdrops to retrospectively reward and distribute tokens to early users. Their implementation uses a Merkle tree which has the advantage of verifying whitelisted addresses in logarithmic time, whereas other methods may require linear time.
15% of the total token supply was minted at genesis to users, historical LPs, and SOCKS holders without any vesting or lock-ups:
Users: 400 UNI per account that ever called a Uniswap pair or router contract.
Historical LPs: pro-rata, weighted by amount of time liquidity was provided, and total ETH value of the provided liquidity.
SOCKS holders: 1000 UNI per account that holds at least 1 SOCKS token, or burns SOCKS.
Github repo with code they used to retroactively determine UNI airdrop recipients.
Criticisms of UNI Airdrop According to a great deep dive by Jack Gorman for Dune Analytics, only about 7% of the 250k initial airdrop recipients still held their UNI tokens at the time the data was captured. Only 1% of recipients increased their UNI holdings. 93% of wallets ‘dumped’ their tokens for the free money. Over 75% of wallets dumped their tokens in the first 7 days. Furthermore, the airdrop seems to have failed at distributing governance and voting power, as today the majority of large UNI holders were not airdrop recipients.
Tomasz Tunguz performs a great analysis of the effectiveness of the UNI airdrop as a marketing channel here. He finds them to be less effective than traditional marketing channels as measured by their payback period.

Gnosis Safe, now known officially as Safe following a strategic raise and spinoff, took a unique approach to its airdrop of SAFE tokens. The team chose to distribute 5% of the total supply of SAFE to users for their past contributions and usage.
The key differentiator of this airdrop is that of the 5%, only half of it will become available to users immediately, while the other half will vest linearly over the next four years. Additionally, and of equal import, the token will initially be non-transferrable until voted upon by SafeDAO, Safe protocol’s governing body. This will discourage dumping of the token, and incentivize further participation. The airdrop has the express goals of decentralizing governance, rewarding usage, and raising awareness for the project, among others.
A Snapshot proposal to unlock the tokens failed (SEP #2 Community Initiative To Unpause Token Contract).
Several months after the initial airdrop the community voted to allocate a portion of unclaimed airdrop tokens to wallets that claimed the first airdrop (SEP #5 Redistriubting Unredeemed Tokens From User Airdrop Allocation).

Worldcoin’s approach to distributing its native token WLD has been widely criticized for the economic design choices made. There is a maximum supply of 10B WLD, as stipulated in the token’s contract. At launch, 143M of these will enter circulation, with 43M of those airdropped to users, with the other 100M loaned to market makers. This means that at launch the only 1.43% of the total supply will be in circulation. The token had a fully diluted value (FDV) of over $30B in its opening hours on the market, in part due to its low float. Many people are concerned that 75% of the tokens maximum supply will enter circulation over the next few years and likely bringing high sell pressure. There are also concerns regarding the loaning of a majority of tokens at launch to market makers. Worldcoin’s official stated purpose for this is to ensure liquidity on exchanges, facilitate price discovery, and enhance price stability. As of October 23, 2023, World Assets Ltd, the legal entity behind Worldcoin, has decided to extend the duration of the loans by another 3 months. Matt Batsinelas of Glass Markets is a bit more skeptical about their motives. The token launched on Optimism. Read more about their tokenomics here (geofenced in the US and other select regions).

19% of OP tokens were allocated for user airdrops. These are planned to be distributed across multiple rounds.
Airdrop 1 distributed 5% of all tokens on June 1st, 2022. Users had to claim their tokens on the official Optimism airdrop app through a merkle tree.
According to their website: This airdrop is targeted towards people who:
Behave in positive-sum ways.
Contribute actively to their communities.
Have been priced out of Ethereum.
Airdrop 2 distributed 0.27% of the total supply. This time to users who had delegated the voting power of their OP tokens, and to users that had paid more than $6.10 in gas fees. Tokens did not need to be claimed - they were sent directly to eligible addresses’ wallets.
Airdrop 3 distributed 0.45% of total supply on Sept 15, 2023 following similar criteria as Airdrop 2 to reward governance participation.
OP holders gain access to the Token House, one of the governing entities in Optimism Collective’s bicameral legislative structure (the other being the Citizens’ House). The Token House votes on protocol upgrades, project incentives as a part of a Governance Fund, and more.

title: All-pay Auction
description: Competitive bidding process where all participants pay their bids, regardless of whether they win or lose. The highest bidder wins the item, but everyone else loses their bid money.
details:
In all-pay auctions, participants either privately or publicly submit their bids and the highest bidder acquires the item. Unlike standard auctions, losing bidders don't get their bids returned. This creates a unique competitive landscape that affects participant behavior and strategy.
All-pay auctions are used in game theory to model situations where competitors invest resources with no guarantee of success, such as political lobbying. They are closely aligned with the concept of "war of attrition," and draw from the Nash equilibrium for optimal strategies.
Advantages & Applications
Limitations & Risks
Key Considerations
Pricing Strategy: Consider setting a reserve price or entry fee to mitigate extreme bidding behavior.
Anti-Collusion Measures: Incorporate rules or algorithms to detect and deter collusive activities.
Information Availability: Decide whether bids will be public or private, as this affects bidding strategy.
Resource Constraints: Keep in mind the economic diversity of your user base; a highly unequal field may result in the system favoring only a subset of wealthier participants.

example_details:
A priority gas auction takes place when network participants (bots) seeking to profit from arbitrage opportunities engage in a transaction fee (gas) bidding war to secure a revenue opportunity. In the end, only one bot will win and secure the profits, but all other auction participants must still pay the gas for their failed transactions (bids).
Source: Flashboys 2.0

Proof of Work (PoW) is the consensus mechanism that underpins cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and demonstrates characteristics of an all-pay auction. In this case, the payment is in the form of the computational power expended to find the right hash. All miners in the network will expend this energy, but there will only be one winner. This winner is rarely the ‘highest bidder’ because the return is probabilistic.
PoW's design can be critiqued for its energy intensity and potential inefficiency, as the 'all-pay' aspect creates a situation where vast amounts of resources are expended without direct productivity aside from network security. This has led to discussions on the sustainability and ethical implications of PoW as a consensus mechanism.
Source: When Blockchain Meets Auction Models: A Survey, Some Applications, and Challenges

Fomo3D was an Ethereum-based game that exemplified the all-pay auction mechanism, where every participant must pay regardless of whether they win or not. Here's how it worked.
Setup:
Fomo3D was set up as a lottery game with a timer counting down.
Players could buy keys (tickets) with Ethereum. Each key purchase extended the game's timer up to a maximum limit, usually 24 hours.
The price of keys increased incrementally as more were bought.
The last person to buy a key when the timer ran out would win the entire prize pool.
Participation Costs:
All players had to pay to participate, hence the all-pay mechanism. Whether they ended up winning or not, their money was kept in the game's contract.
Incentive to Play:
The prospect of winning a large prize pool incentivized continuous participation.
Dividends: Keyholders received a portion of the ETH from each new key purchase, creating passive income for participants.
Game Theory Dynamics:
Rational players would assess the probability of winning against the cost of participating and potential reward.
As the timer got lower, the incentive to be the last keyholder increased, leading to a flurry of activity and increased prices towards the end.
Endgame:
The game would theoretically end when no new keys were purchased before the timer ran out.
In practice, this led to aggressive competition towards the end, with bots and large players trying to be the last buyer.
Critique and Outcomes:
It created a situation where the most invested players were likely those who spent the most but did not win, illustrating the 'all-pay' principle.
The game was criticized for being similar to a Ponzi scheme, with late participants paying earlier ones, and a high likelihood of loss.
It raised questions about the ethical and practical implications of such games on blockchain technology.
For a more in-depth critique, see Matt Stephenson's 2018 post Ethereum, FOMO3D, and Dangerous Game Theory.

title: Approval Voting
description: A voting mechanism that allows voters to express approval for multiple options simultaneously. The winner is the option with the highest number of approvals.
details:
Each voter can vote for one or more options by "approving" them. Unlike traditional voting systems, where voters select a single candidate, this method offers a more nuanced approach.Each of the voter’s choices is weighted equally, and the option with the most votes emerges as the winner.
Approval Voting draws its foundations from social choice theory, a branch of political science and economics concerned with aggregating individual preferences to make collective decisions. It is a simpler alternative to ranked-choice voting methods like Instant Runoff Voting (IRV) or Single Transferable Vote (STV).
Advantages & Applications
Simplicity: Approval Voting is easy for both voters and administrators to understand and implement.
Reduction of strategic voting: Voters can express their true preferences without fear of vote-splitting or wasted votes.
Broad representation: This mechanism tends to produce winners who are broadly acceptable to the electorate.
Uses: This mechanism can be useful in elections, to help with budgeting decisions, ratification of legislation, among others. See examples section for more.
Limitations & Risks
Majority dominance: Approval Voting can favor options that are only moderately preferred by many voters, potentially neglecting options with passionate but smaller support bases.
Lack of expressiveness: It doesn't capture nuanced preferences as ranking systems do, potentially sacrificing granularity in decision-making.
Tactical voting: While strategic voting is less common, it can still occur when voters have strong opinions about certain options.
Key Considerations
Balance between breadth and depth: Designers must consider the trade-off between selecting broadly acceptable options and capturing the depth of voter preferences.
Threshold setting: Establishing the approval threshold (the number of approvals needed to win) is crucial; it can influence the outcome significantly.
Voter education: Ensuring voters understand how to use Approval Voting effectively and without fear of making mistakes is essential.
This entry was coauthored by Alex Weseley.

example_details:
DappHub uses approval voting to elect a "chief" contract.
In this implementation “voters lock up voting tokens to give their votes weight. Users get IOU tokens any time they lock voting tokens... The IOU tokens may not be exchanged for the locked tokens except by someone who has actually locked funds in the contract, and only up to the amount they have locked.”
Smart contract implementation written in Cadence, the programming language created by Flow.

Snapshot is a popular token voting tool that supports various types of voting. This demo shows how approval voting could be used to ratify the articles of a DAO's constitution.
Additional instances of Snapshot approval voting in action: Optimism 1, Optimism 2, ENS, Uniswap.

title: Assurance Contract
description: Participants pledge money to fund a project. If the funding goal is met by a specified deadline, the pledges are collected and the good is provided. If the project fails to reach its funding goal, participants receive a refund.
details:
In an Assurance Contract, individuals pledge money towards a public good or service. If the project reaches its funding target by a specified deadline, the money is collected, and the project is executed. If the target is not met, pledges are returned to the contributors. This mechanism addresses the collective action problem and aims to overcome the hesitation individuals have in contributing to a project without assurance that the project will be successfully funded.
Assurance Contracts are rooted in game theory and draw from concepts related to the provision of public goods. They address the challenge of motivating individuals to contribute to projects where there is uncertainty about the project's success, a classic problem in economics and social science.
Assurance contracts were heavily used in the ICO era, commonly known as "soft caps".
Advantages & Applications
Risk Mitigation: Contributors aren't charged unless the goal is met.
Fosters Collective Action: Encourages public participation by providing a safety net against project failure, which can lead to greater collective contributions.
Flexible Funding Goals: Funding thresholds can be adjusted to fit the project's needs, making it adaptable to various initiatives.
Limitations & Risks
Free-Rider Problem: There is a risk of individuals benefiting from the project without contributing, as they can wait for others to fund it.
Wait-and-See Problem: There may be no strong incentive to pledge if project success is uncertain. Potential contributors may delay pledging until the last moment, causing uncertainty and risking project failure.
Key Considerations
Funding Threshold: Mechanism designers should accurately gauge the minimum viable funding required to ensure project success. Setting the threshold too high might deter contributions, while setting it too low may risk project failure.
Time Constraints: Determining an optimal duration for the funding period is crucial. Too short a period may not allow sufficient time for contributions to accumulate, while too long a period may lead to procrastination among potential contributors.

example_details: This contract allows users to get a refund if the funding goal is not met.

Classic crowdfunding platform where projects must reach some threshold of funding before backers are charged for their contributions. If the threshold is not met, backers get their money back.
They are currently looking into converting their centralized platform into a blockchain-based protocol.

title: Automated Market-Maker (AMM)
description: Decentralized exchange mechanism that employs a mathematical algorithm, known as a bonding curve, to establish the price of an asset in response to market supply and demand dynamics.
details:
AMMs facilitate the trading of digital assets, by eliminating the need for traditional order books and intermediaries. Instead, they rely on smart contracts.
Here's how it functions: When a user wants to trade one digital asset for another within an AMM-based decentralized exchange, they interact with a smart contract. This contract is responsible for maintaining a liquidity pool, which contains pairs of assets, e.g., Ethereum and DAI. Users can deposit their assets into these pools in exchange for pool tokens that represent their share of the pool's liquidity.
The bonding curve algorithm dynamically adjusts the price of assets within the pool based on the ratio of assets held. As one asset becomes scarcer (i.e., more users trade for it), its price increases according to the curve. Conversely, if users sell an asset, its price decreases. This ensures that the pool always maintains a balance between the two assets.
Traders can swap one asset for another by interacting with the smart contract, which automatically calculates the appropriate exchange rate based on the bonding curve's algorithm. As more users trade, the bonding curve adapts, allowing the market to find a new equilibrium price continuously.
Advantages & Applications
Liquidity: They provide continuous liquidity for various digital assets, enabling trading at any time.
Accessibility: AMMs are accessible to anyone with an internet connection, democratizing access to financial markets.
Efficiency: The automated pricing mechanism and use of smart contracts reduces the need for intermediaries and allows for 24/7 trading.
Token Launches: AMMs are used for initial token offerings (ICOs) and liquidity bootstrapping events, simplifying token distribution.
Limitations & Risks
Impermanent Loss: Liquidity providers may experience losses due to price divergence between the assets in the pool and external market prices.
Limited Price Discovery: AMMs may struggle with providing accurate price information for assets with low liquidity.
Front-Running: Vulnerabilities in AMM smart contracts can be exploited by malicious actors to front-run or manipulate trades.
Slippage: For larger trades, the price may deviate significantly from the expected rate due to the bonding curve.
Key Considerations
Liquidity Management: Designers must consider strategies for attracting and retaining liquidity providers, as this is critical for the AMM's performance.
Security: Ensuring the smart contracts are secure and free from vulnerabilities is paramount to prevent exploitation.
Slippage Tolerance: AMM parameters must be set to accommodate users' tolerance for price slippage.
Pair Selection: Choosing the right asset pairs to create liquidity pools is essential for effective operation.
Bonding Curve: Depending on the intended use of the liquidity pools in the exchange, developers must decide which pricing function they want to implement. Today, most AMMs are some form of Constant Function Market Maker such as Constant Sum, Constant Product, Constant Mean, or some combination of these. Each will result to different levels of liquidity, price impact, and slippage. See here for more information.
Number of Assets in Pools: Designers must consider how many assets each liquidity pool can have, as well as the price volatility of these assets. This will have implications on the curve function to be chosen. Some AMMs exclusively allow for dual-asset pools (Uniswap, Curve), while others allow for multi-asset pools (Balancer).
This entry was coauthored by Alex Weseley.

resources.resource: Formal Specification of Constant Product Market Maker
Automated Market Making: Theory and Practice

example_details: A Constant Function Market Maker (CFMM) implementation which became popular for providing low-fees and low-slippage in stablecoin pools (e.g. DAI - USDC). It introduced a novel “amplification coefficient” in its pricing function which allows for low-slippage. It uses a combination of constant product and constant sum functions to achieve this. For more information check out: Whitepaper.

The biggest decentralized exchange (DEX) by volume. It is primarily known for pioneering Constant Product Market Makers (CPMM), a specific class of AMM that uses the constant product formula to price assets in a pool. The formula is $x*y = k$, where $x$ and $y$ are the amount of each token held in the pool, respectively, and $k$ is a constant. The latest version is Uniswap V3, which introduced methods to improve capital efficiency.
How Bancor Liquidity Pools Work

The balancer protocol implements a generalized version of the Constant Mean Market Maker that allows for $n$-token pools (where 2 ≤ $n$ ≤ 50), users-defined weights, and customizable fees. It’s value proposition lies in its customizability which enables the creation of weighted pools, stable pools, and managed pools.

title: Batch Auction
description: Groups individual orders and executes them simultaneously at a uniform clearing price.
details:
Batch auctions aggregate buy and sell orders over a specified period and execute them simultaneously at a uniform clearing price. This price is determined when the total quantity of buy orders equals the total quantity of sell orders, ensuring market equilibrium. Unlike continuous trading, where orders are matched in real-time, batch auctions consolidate liquidity at discrete intervals. By aggregating orders, batch auctions can minimize the price impact of large individual trades, protect against MEV attacks, improve price discovery, and enhance gas efficiency in blockchain contexts.
The concept of batch auctions originates from market microstructure theory and auction theory in economics and finance. Batch auctions gained relevance on-chain in the late 2010s as a potential solution to front-running and MEV issues. One of the early implementations was the Gnosis Protocol, now CoW Protocol, launched in 2020. Since then, various DEXs have adopted batch auctions, including dYdX. Besides being used for trading, batched auctions have also been used as a fundraising mechanism with fair price discovery, such as in the case of Gnosis Auctions.
Variations
Dual-asset batch auctions: Trades are executed between two specific assets, with the clearing price determined based on the intersection of supply and demand for those assets.
Multi-asset batch auctions: Trades involving multiple assets are executed simultaneously, facilitating complex trade combinations and ring trades where several assets can be exchanged in a single transaction sequence.
Advantages & Applications
Reduced Market Impact: By aggregating orders, batch auctions can minimize the price impact of large individual orders, benefiting institutional investors and traders with significant positions.
MEV Protection: Can shield users from MEV attacks by removing the time advantage typically front-runners exploit.
Improved Price Discovery: Aggregating orders can lead to more accurate and stable pricing, especially in less liquid markets.
Gas Efficiency: Batching multiple trades into a single transaction can significantly reduce gas costs for users.
Limitations & Risks
Reduced Immediacy: The periodic nature of batch auctions means that orders are not executed instantly, which may be unsuitable for time-sensitive trades. If significant market movements occur between batches, this can lead to outdated prices.
Potential for Gaming: Sophisticated participants might attempt to manipulate the auction by submitting strategic bids before the cutoff time.
Liquidity Concerns: In markets with low trading volume, batch auctions might not have sufficient liquidity to function effectively.
Design Considerations
Auction Frequency: Determine the optimal interval between auctions to balance liquidity aggregation with execution speed.
Clearing Price Mechanism: Design a fair and efficient algorithm for determining the uniform clearing price that maximizes executed volume. Create appropriate incentives for solvers who compute optimal order matching if necessary.
Order Types: Consider supporting various order types (e.g., limit orders or pegged orders) to cater to different trading strategies.
Cross-Asset Interactions: In multi-asset batch auctions, carefully model how trades in different assets can affect each other within the same batch.

resources.resource: A Deep Dive into Batch Auctions (Bell Curve)
Batch Auctions vs. Dutch Auctions in Crypto (CoW Protocol)
Batch Auctions: The New Trading Mechanism for DeFi (Richard Larsson)

example_details: Implements batch auctions for decentralized trading, allowing for multi-asset swaps and MEV protection. The protocol collects and aggregates orders off-chain and settles them in batches. These batches are then auctioned off to solvers who offer the most surplus for the orders, ensuring uniform clearing prices and minimizing the risk of MEV extraction.

Employs Frequent Batch Auctions (FBA) where orders are grouped together in batches. Each batch undergoes an auction and a single uniform price is chosen to maximize traded volume. Orders whose limit prices cross the uniform price are matched by price priority. If multiple orders share the same price, they participate in trades pro-rata.

Enables projects to conduct Initial DEX Offerings through batch auctions. The project determines the minimum price they are willing to sell their tokens for, and bidders set the maximum price they are willing to pay. At the end of the batch auction, all trades are settled based on where the buying demand and token supply meet. This way both participants get either what they were willing to receive or more.

title: Bounty
description: A pre-specified task and reward for anyone who completes a specific task or achieving within a particular ecosystem.

title: Burn-and-Mint Equilibrium (BME)
description: Users burn tokens to access network services, reducing the token supply, while service providers receive new tokens minted at a controlled but independent rate.
details:
In BME, tokens burned by users represent service consumption, effectively removing these tokens from circulation. This action directly correlates with the utilization of network services, which can be priced an external currency like USD so that the number of tokens burnt per unit of service can fluctuate rather than their actual cost to users.
Independently, the network issues new tokens at a predetermined rate, allocating them to service providers in proportion to their contributions. Crucially, the global minting rate is not linked to the rate of burning, which–all else equal– can allow for an increase in token value when the rate of burning exceeds minting. This model encourages a positive correlation between service demand and token price.
Advantages & Applications:
Stabilized Service Pricing: Provides a stable pricing model for services on decentralized networks.
Value Growth with Network Usage: As service usage increases (and more tokens are burned), the token's value can increase, benefiting the network and its participants.
Fair Compensation for Service Providers: Ensures that service providers are compensated in a manner that is both sustainable and potentially profitable.
Limitations & Risks:
Complex Economic Balance: Achieving the ideal equilibrium between burning and minting is challenging and requires constant monitoring and adjustments.
Susceptibility to Market Dynamics: The model can be sensitive to large fluctuations in service usage or speculative trading behaviors.
Implementation Challenges: Particularly for ERC20 tokens, the burn mechanism can create gas inefficiencies.
Key Considerations:
Decoupling Minting and Burning Rates: Designers should ensure that the minting rate is not directly correlated with the burning rate, allowing for value appreciation as burning increases.
Ensuring Provider Profitability: The minting rate must be calibrated to cover the costs of service providers and ideally offer profitability, balancing the ecosystem’s economic incentives.
Adapting to Service Demand Fluctuations: The mechanism must be flexible enough to adapt to changes in network usage and service demand to maintain economic stability.

resources.resource: Burn and Mint Equilibrium Pro's and Cons

example_details:
The Helium network, a decentralized wireless platform, utilizes the Burn and Mint Equilibrium (BME) model in its token economy through its native Helium Token (HNT). In this implementation, the burning of HNT tokens produces Data Credits (DC), which are used within the network. Here's how the BME model functions in the context of Helium:
Token Burning (Using Services): Users of the Helium network burn HNT tokens to obtain Data Credits. Data Credits are non-transferable credits used to pay for network services, such as transmitting data over the network. This process of burning HNT to acquire DC reduces the available supply of HNT.
Token Minting (Compensation for Service Providers): On the other side, the Helium network mints new HNT tokens periodically. These minted tokens are distributed to network participants who provide valuable services to the network. For instance, those who operate Helium hotspots — devices that create coverage for the network — are rewarded with newly minted HNT tokens.
Adapting to Network Usage: The Helium network's tokenomics is designed to adapt in real-time to its usage patterns. As the demand for network services increases (more HNT burned for Data Credits), the value of HNT is expected to rise, given a controlled minting rate. Conversely, if the demand decreases, the value would adjust accordingly.

title: Buyback & Burn
description: A financial mechanism aimed at increasing the value of a token by repurchasing it from the open market and then permanently removing it from circulation through burning.
details:
In the buyback and burn model, a network uses its generated income to buy back its native tokens from the market and burns them, effectively reducing the total supply. This is intended to increase the scarcity and, theoretically, the value of each remaining token. The tokens are usually burned by sending them to an irretrievable address, making them unusable.
The mechanism is inspired by stock buybacks in traditional finance and also incorporates concepts from the Quantity Theory of Money. According to this theory, the value of money is tied to its supply and velocity, as well as the price and quantity of goods and services in an economy. The theory is often represented by the equation "MV = PQ." In the context of "Buyback & Burn," reducing the supply of tokens (akin to the money supply, or "M" in the equation) aims to increase their value (akin to the price level, or "P") assuming that other variables like velocity ("V") and quantity of services ("Q") remain constant. This posits that reducing the supply of a token will, all else being equal, increase its price.
Advantages & Applications
Price Support: Helps in stabilizing or increasing token price.
Simplicity: Easier to implement and understand compared to more complex mechanisms.
Transparency: Burning events are publicly verifiable on the blockchain.
Limitations & Risks
Short-Term Focus: May not contribute to long-term project development.
Regulatory Risk: May be seen as a form of market manipulation in some jurisdictions.
Irreversible: Once tokens are burned, they cannot be recovered.
Key Considerations

resources.resource: MakerDAO Teardown: Burning all the way to the bank

example_details: The original Binance Coin used a quarterly "Buyback & Burn" based on revenues from its centralized crypto exchange.

In MakerDAO, the MKR token serves a dual purpose as both a governance token and an economic instrument subject to a "Buyback & Burn" mechanism.
Governance MKR token holders have the authority to vote on various aspects of the Maker system, including stability fee rates, collateral types, and system upgrades. This governance model allows decentralized control over the MakerDAO ecosystem.
Fee Capture through Buyback & Burn Upon paying down a collateralized debt position in DAI to retreive the underslying collateral, the user must also pay a 'stability fee.' This fee is converted into MKR tokens on the open market and then burned, effectively reducing the total supply. This aims to increase the value of remaining MKR tokens as a mechanism for MKR holders to capture network fees.

examples.example: EIP-1559: Fee market change for ETH 1.0 chain

title: Buyback & Make
description: A financial mechanism aimed at increasing the utility and value of a token within a decentralized network by repurchasing tokens and allocating them to productive use.
details:
In traditional "buy and burn" models, tokens are repurchased from the open market and destroyed to reduce supply and increase scarcity. The "Buyback & Make" model modifies this by repurchasing tokens and reallocating them to a network-owned "smart pool." This serves multiple purposes: it acts as an automatic buyback machine, a token issuance pool, and a liquidity provider. Instead of burning the tokens, which could hinder long-term value, they are used for future issuance or other productive purposes. This model capitalizes on programmable liquidity to automate these operations, drastically simplifying code and design.
The buyback and burn model is rooted in stock buyback practices from traditional corporate financial management while also incorporating principles from Keynesian economics regarding the reinvestment of capital to stimulate economic growth. This approach focuses on capital assets whose value comes from governance or economic participation. It challenges the notion that scarcity through burning automatically implies value, and instead proposes a model that enhances liquidity, issuance, and governance.
Advantages & Applications
Efficient Capital Utilization: No capital is destroyed, allowing for reinvestment.
Automated Operations: Utilizes smart pools for automatic buybacks and issuance.
Dynamic Liquidity Management: Can adjust to market conditions via protocol governance.
Price Stability: Can help stabilize token price during market downturns.
Sustainability: Promotes long-term growth by continually capitalizing the system.
Limitations & Risks
Governance Risks: Requires robust governance for effective fund allocation.
Complexity: Smart pool settings need meticulous tuning and oversight.
Market Impact: Sudden large buybacks can distort market prices.
Regulatory Risks: Legal concerns if tokens have security-like attributes.
Key Considerations

title: Capped Returns
description: A mechanism where the returns on an investment are limited to a certain percentage or amount.

title: Coin Machine
description: Sells limited amounts of tokens in fixed-price batches, adjusting prices up or down in between sale periods based on recent demand.

title: Collateralized Debt Position (CDP)
description: Locking up collateral in one token to take out a loan worth less in a different token. The loan must be paid back to unlock the collateral. The loan can be liquidated if the value of the collateral drops below the value of the loan (or comes close enough).

title: Competitive Vote-Based Issuance
description: Contributors submit proposals or content, and token holders within the community cast votes to determine which contributors receive the new token issuance.
details: Contributors, such as developers, writers, or creators, present their work to the community. Existing token holders then vote on these submissions, with their voting power typically proportional to their token holdings. The voting process is competitive, as only a limited number of contributors with the highest number of votes receive the new token issuance. The awarded tokens can grant various rights, like governance participation, access to platform features, or publication rights.

title: Conditional Token
description: Can be redeemed at a particular value based on the outcome of specific conditions or events.
details:
Conditional tokens are tradable assets representing potential outcomes of interconnected events within a single market structure. These tokens are created for specific events or conditions, with each token corresponding to a possible outcome. Multiple conditions can be linked, forming a tree-like structure of potential outcomes representing complex scenarios with interdependent events. The underlying smart contract manages the relationships between different conditions, ensuring token fungibility across layers. Users can trade these tokens, effectively betting on the likelihood of various outcomes. When an event occurs, the outcome is verified, often using oracles or external data feeds, and tokens are redeemed based on the result. This structure enables more nuanced information discovery compared to simple binary outcome tokens, as it preserves fungibility in deeper layers of combinatorial markets.
The concept of conditional tokens originates from prediction markets and information economics. Gnosis pioneered its development in the blockchain context by introducing the Conditional Token Framework in 2019. Since their introduction, conditional tokens have been implemented by various platforms, such as Polymarket, to create prediction markets on a wide range of topics, from politics to cryptocurrency prices.
Advantages & Applications
Enhanced Information Discovery: Allows for more granular insights into the relationships between different events and their outcomes.
Flexibility: Supports the creation of simple markets for single events and complex, multi-condition markets.
Fungibility: Maintains token fungibility in deeper layers of combinatorial markets, improving liquidity and trading efficiency.
Limitations & Risks
Liquidity Fragmentation: As markets become more complex, liquidity might be spread thin across numerous conditional outcomes.
Oracle Dependence: Relies on accurate and timely reporting of event outcomes, which can be vulnerable to manipulation or errors.
Market Inefficiencies: In nascent or illiquid markets, prices may not accurately reflect true probabilities, leading to potential mispricing.
Design Considerations
Event Selection: Choose clearly definable events with unambiguous outcomes to ensure market integrity.
Market Structure: Carefully design the hierarchy and relationships between conditions to maximize information value.
Liquidity Provision: Implement incentives to ensure sufficient liquidity across various conditional outcomes.
Outcome Reporting: Establish robust oracle systems or decentralized reporting mechanisms for determining event outcomes.

resources.resource: A short primer on Conditional Tokens (Gnosis)
Conditional Tokens - Introduction to a new Asset Class (Stephan George)

example_details: Utilizes Gnosis’ Conditional Token Framework to represent binary outcomes (YES and NO) for prediction markets. These are implemented as ERC1155 tokens on the Polygon network. The system utilizes three key operations: SPLIT, MERGE, and REDEEM. SPLIT allows users to create outcome tokens by dividing collateral (e.g., USDC) into equal amounts of each position token. MERGE, the inverse operation, enables users to combine a full set of outcome tokens back into collateral. REDEEM allows users to exchange winning outcome tokens for collateral after the condition is resolved and the oracle reports payouts.

title: Continuous Auction
description: Repeating auction to sell newly created NFTs from collection on a recurring basis. The highest bidder receives the NFT, and all proceeds go to a treasury that is governed by the NFT holders. Auctions can occur at any chosen interval, with a common default being daily.
details: Continuous Auctions offer a steady flow of funds for the organization's treasury and controlled growth of its governing membership. Although not every auction results in a new member, it offers a daily opportunity for potential members to join. This gradual expansion helps establish the DAO's culture and norms, benefiting new members by allowing them to join a less overwhelming, slower-growing organization compared to one with a rapid influx of members.

title: Contract Secured Revenue (CSR)
description: Allows contract creators to receive a portion of the gas fees consumed by their contracts within a given block.

resources.resource: Introducing CIP-1 Contract Secured Revenue (CSR): Tokenized Fee Sharing for Canto Builders

examples.example: EIP-6968: Contract Secured Revenue on an EVM based L2

title: Conviction Voting
description: Proposals are passed based on aggregated continuous preferences of community members.
details: Funds proposals based on the aggregated preference of community members, expressed continuously. In other words, voters are always asserting their preference for which proposals they would like to see approved, rather than casting votes in a single time-boxed session. A member can change their preference at any time, but the longer they keep their preference for the same proposal, the “stronger” their conviction gets. This added conviction gives long standing community members with consistent preferences more influence than short term participants merely trying to influence a vote.

resources.resource: Conviction Voting: A Novel Continuous Decision Making Alternative to Governance

title: Correlation Discount
description: Reducing the weight of correlated opinions to mitigate the overrepresentation of popular views and balance the influence across different voter segments. By recognizing and adjusting for the correlation among voters' preferences, this mechanism aims to enhance the fairness and representativeness of collective decisions.
details:
The concept of "correlation discounting" as described in the paper "Decentralized Society: Finding Web3’s Soul" by Puja Ohlhaver, E. Glen Weyl, and Vitalik Buterin, refers to a method for adjusting the influence or weight of individual votes in collective decision-making processes, such as DAO voting or public goods funding. The key idea is to discount votes that are highly correlated with each other to prevent overrepresentation of synchronized groups and to promote more diverse and independent decision-making.
In practical terms, this means if a group of voters have similar attributes or have demonstrated similar voting behaviors (high correlation), their collective voting power might be reduced compared to a more diverse group of voters whose decisions are less aligned (low correlation). This approach aims to balance the influence among participants and protect the system from being dominated by a cohesive subgroup, thereby encouraging a more equitable and representative governance structure.
This mechanism is a part of broader efforts to enhance governance in decentralized systems by considering the diversity of perspectives and reducing the risk of majoritarian domination or manipulation by well-coordinated groups.

example_details:
COCM (Connection Oriented Cluster Match) works in three steps.
First, it takes in data about “clusters”, which are just different (possibly overlapping) groups of users. You could generate cluster data from POAPs, twitter follower lists, or even the donation records (where if someone donates to project X, they’re put in project X’s cluster). Users can also have “weights” in a cluster, denoting how strongly they belong to it. For example, you could use github repositories as clusters, where if I make n pull requests to that repository, I have a weight of n in that repository’s cluster. In general, round operators can choose what cluster data to use (or they can not use COCM at all, of course).
COCM calculates “similarity scores” between each user and each cluster.
Finally, COCM runs QF, but then attenuates each project’s funding if many of its donors are similar according to the scores calculated in step 2.

title: Crowdfund
description: Collecting funds without necessarily issuing a token in exchange.

example_details:
Classic crowdfunding platform where projects must reach some threshold of funding before backers are charged for their contributions. If the threshold is not met, backers get their money back.
They are currently looking into converting their centralized platform into a blockchain-based protocol.

The project creates a crowdfunding campaign and rallies supporters to donate.
During the campaign, the project hosts multiple lucky draws - but the winners do not recieve prizes immediately.
If the campaign reaches the target, the project receives funding and winners receive prizes. If not, all donors get a full refund.

title: Crowdsale
description: Raising funds for a project by issuing new tokens to purchasers. These tokens can represent a mix of rights including governance, economic, or access to a product or service.

example_details: This contract allows users to get a refund if the funding goal is not met.

title: Curation Markets
description: Reduce information asymmetry through the use of tokenized signals. Tokens are minted as needed through a continuous token model.

resources.resource: Curved Token Bonding in Curation Markets
Desire Paths and Markets for Recommendation

example_details:
The Graph Network utilizes curation markets to reduce information asymmetries about subgraphs. By incentivizing curators (i.e. token holders) to curate high-quality subgraphs, Indexers are able to index quality data sources much faster.
The Graph uses a curved bonding system that gives curators a gradient score of the relevance of their curation work. To accomplish this, Curators signal on attractive subgraphs by minting the curation shares of a particular subgraph. The earlier a curator signals on a subgraph by minting its curation shares, the greater the share of query fees they can earn.

title: DAICO
description: Allows token holders to control the gradual release of funds to a project after fundraising.
details:
A DAICO combines an initial coin offering (ICO) with a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) structure. The process begins with an ICO to raise capital, after which all funds are locked into a smart contract controlled by token holders. This smart contract implements a "tap" mechanism, allowing a gradual release of funds to the development team at a specific rate measured in wei/sec. Token holders can vote to adjust this tap rate, effectively controlling the flow of funds based on the project’s progress. If dissatisfied with the project’s direction, token holders can vote to "turn off the tap" or even initiate a refund process, returning the remaining funds to contributors. This mechanism maintains developer motivation while providing investors with ongoing influence over fund allocation and project direction.
Vitalik Buterin introduced the DAICO concept in 2018 on the ethresear.ch forum. It emerged as a response to the 2017 ICO boom, which saw numerous projects mismanage raised funds or engage in fraudulent activities. Since its introduction, DAICOs have been adopted by several blockchain projects, though not as widely as initially anticipated. Notable implementations include Aragon’s Fundraising App.
Advantages & Applications
Accountability: Ensures that developers are accountable to token holders, reducing the risk of fund mismanagement.
Balances Community Involvement & Team Control: Offers a middle ground between token holder control and project autonomy. Token holders act as a safeguard against fund misuse without interfering in day-to-day operations, while the project retains control over released funds.
Mitigation of Scams: Reduces the likelihood of exit scams by allowing the community to halt funding if the project fails to deliver.
Flexibility: Can be adapted to various contribution models (e.g., capped sales, dutch auctions, or interactive offerings) while maintaining the core governance structure.
Limitations & Risks
Limited Granularity in Accountability: The binary nature of the “kill switch” mechanism lacks nuance, offering only an all-or-nothing approach. While effective against extreme cases like scams, it fails to provide incremental feedback or incentivize team responsiveness in less severe scenarios.
Consensus Requirement Overrides Individual Concerns: Individual token holders cannot withdraw their share of funds based on personal dissatisfaction. Instead, it requires group consensus, potentially disregarding minority concerns and limiting the system’s responsiveness to diverse viewpoints.
Potential for Manipulation: Large token holders could potentially sway votes, especially if the project members hold a significant portion of tokens.
Voter Apathy: Low participation in voting processes could undermine the effectiveness of the governance mechanism.
Design Considerations
Voting Mechanism: Design a fair and efficient voting mechanism to ensure active participation and accurate representation of token holders.
Incentive Alignment: Ensure that the incentive structures align the interests of project members and token holders to foster cooperation and project success.
Transparency: Maintain transparency in project development and fund allocation to build trust among the community.

resources.resource: What is a DAICO, Explained (Chrisjan Pauw)

example_details: Utilizes a bonding curve where funds are split between a reserve pool and a discretionary vault. A tap mechanism controls the flow of funds from the former to the latter over time. This structure aligns with DAICO concepts by providing ongoing liquidity and allowing token holders to vote on fund allocation.

title: DAO Options
description: Tokenized options that give the holder the right to buy or sell tokens in the DAO. Can be used for an airdrop, as liquidity incentives, or to motivate contributors.

title: Decentralized Identifier (DID)
description: Unique identifiers that allow entities to be identified in a verifiable and persistent way without relying on a centralized registry. They can be used to identify entities such as persons, organizations, or Internet of Things (IoT) devices.
details: DIDs form the basis for self-sovereign identity (SSI), a decentralized digital identity model that gives individuals control over their own identity information. Self-sovereign identity allows individuals to control their own identity information and use it to access websites, services, and applications without depending on large identity providers. This prevents fragmentation of online experiences and ensures a secure, streamlined access to services while maintaining control over personal information.

example_details:
The Zuzalu Passport allows Zuzalu residents to store personal data relating to Zuzalu identity, reputation, activity, and more, and to share any part of this data with any (physical and digital) Zuzalu service or app of their choosing.
Under the hood, the Zuzalu Passport stores cryptographically-manipulable data such as keypairs, credentials, attestations, and more, and uses a very lightweight standard for arbitrary zero-knowledge proofs to pass along this data to applications.

title: Delegated Allocation
description: Giving individual allocators budgets and discretion to support projects and people they believe in.
details: Budgets can be renewed and increased or decreased based on the impact of each individual's previous allocations. There can also be incentives for the allocators based on impact or budget size.

title: Demurrage
description: A negative interest rate applied to currency or tokens held in a particular ecosystem, incentivizing spending and discouraging hoarding.

title: Dispute Resolution Game
description: Jurors vote on the outcome of disputes, and the majority decision is considered the final verdict. Honest jurors are rewarded, and dishonest jurors are penalized, reinforcing the integrity of the system.

title: Dividend
description: A portion of profits or revenue distributed to token holders.

title: Dominant Assurance Contract (DAC)
description: Participants pledge money to fund a project. If the funding goal is met by a specified deadline, the pledges are collected and the good is provided. If the project fails to reach its funding goal, participants receive a monetary bonus in addition to a refund.
details:
In a standard assurance contract, participants are guaranteed a refund if a project fails to reach its funding goal. DACs build upon this by offering an additional bonus to contributors in addition to the refund if the project does not reach its goal. This conditional bonus serves to incentivize contributions and signals confidence in the project's viability, thereby making it a dominant strategy to participate even if one doubts the project will succeed.
The idea was first articulated by Alex Tabarrok, 1998. The concept is rooted in game theory, specifically within the context of public goods and the free-rider problem.
Advantages & Applications
Solves Free-Rider Problem: Resolves collective action problems by aligning participant incentives.
Efficient Allocation: Only funds projects with sufficient public interest.
Signaling: The bonus acts as a signal of confidence in the project.
Uses: Common applications include crowdfunding for decentralized and community-based projects.
Limitations & Risks
Coordination Costs: High initial setup complexity.
Lack of Long-Term Commitment: No guarantee for sustained contributions.
Potential for Abuse: Malicious actors might exploit the bonus mechanism, contributing privately and then encouraging others not to contribute publicly.
Upfront Capital Requirement: Requires the project to stake the initial capital required for the bonus.
Key Considerations
Bonus Calculation: Carefully set the bonus amount to be attractive but not exploitable.
Early Sign-up Bonus: Consider the optimal design of the bonus to mitigate the "wait-and-see" problem by rewarding earlier contributors more, but not so much that it reduces the incentive for later participants.
This entry was coauthored by Scott Auriat.

resources.resource: Alexander Tabarrok: The private provision of public goods via dominant assurance contracts

example_details:
The project creates a crowdfunding campaign and rallies supporters to donate.
If the campaign reaches the target, the project is funded. If not, all donors get a full refund and a 20% bonus (paid by the project).
For example: If you donated $1,000 and the campaign does not reach the target, you would recieve a $1,200 refund.

t0wn is a community of real people who are looking to purchase a co-working space and create an innovation hub. The concept is similar to Zuzalu, but on a smaller scale and with year-round special educational events.
To fund the project, they are utilizing Dominant Assurance Contracts, crowdfunding money from a collection of DAOs and Web3 organizations. These organizations will collectively utilize and govern the innovation hub.

title: Dutch Auction
description: An auction where the price of an asset starts high and gradually decreases over time.

title: Dynamic Parameter Tuning
description: Adjusts system parameters in real-time based on predefined criteria to optimize system performance or meet specific objectives.
details:
Dynamic parameter tuning involves the real-time monitoring of system metrics against predefined performance goals. Algorithms evaluate real-time data and update system parameters to achieve desired outcomes.
This mechanism stems from control theory and optimization algorithms, particularly those involving feedback loops. It allows for self-adjusting systems that adapt to fluctuating conditions without manual intervention.
Advantages & Applications
Efficiency: Optimizes system resources by automatically adjusting parameters.
Adaptability: Can cope with varying conditions without manual intervention.
Applications: Useful in load balancing, congestion control, and auction systems within distributed environments.
Limitations & Risks
Overfitting: Risk of tuning to local maxima or short-term conditions. This may lead to oscillations or system instabilities if not properly configured.
Complexity: Adding layers of adaptability can complicate system design.
Vulnerability: Potential for exploitation if malicious actors understand the tuning algorithm.
Key Considerations
Monitoring Metrics: Determine the most relevant metrics to monitor and adjust.
Parameter Sensitivity: Consider how quickly the parameter should change in response to the monitored metrics. Popular algorithms include moving average, exponential moving average, and logarithmic moving average.
Validation: Test the algorithm rigorously under different conditions to ensure stability. Consider backtesting on historical data before deployment.
Security: Implement protective measures against potential exploits. Consider fallback mechanisms in case of algorithmic failure.

example_details: Automatically adjusts the difficulty of proof-of-work calculations based on total network hashing power.

In Ethereum, there is no block size limit, but there is a block gas limit. Each block has a target size of 15 million gas, but the size of blocks will increase or decrease in accordance with network demands, up until the block limit of 30 million gas (2x target block size).
Dynamic pricing mechanisms for transaction fees based on network demand.

title: Escrow
description: A mechanism where funds or tokens are held in a neutral account until certain conditions are met.

example_details: Includes option for simple escrow, conditional escrow, and refund escrow.

WannaBet is an onchain peer-to-peer betting tool that aims to improve upon the trust and logistics prevalent in informal offchain betting among individuals.
Key features include:
Smart Contract Escrow: Funds are held in a non-custodial smart contract, rather than a wallet controlled by an individual
Onchain Bet Terms: All bet details, including description, amount, proposer, recipient, and arbitrator, are stored on the blockchain, ensuring transparency and immutability
Designated Judge: A third-party judge can be used as the source of truth for the outcome of the bet. The smart contract is configured in a way where the judge can only release funds to the proposer, acceptor, or in a tie
User-Friendly Interface: A way to interact with the smart contracts and view others bets
The betting process on WannaBet involves three main steps:
Proposal: A user initiates a bet by specifying the terms, amount, recipient, and judge
Response: The recipient can accept or decline the bet within a specified timeframe
Settlement: The designated judge determines the outcome and releases funds to the winner

title: Fair Ranking
description: Adaption of token curated registries (TCRs) where information which ranks highly is provably valuable to network stakeholders.
details:
Fair Rankings are an economic system for curating information with no single point of failure and no owner, where information which ranks highly is provably valuable to network stakeholders, while protecting against the rich.
Whoever stakes the most tokens ranks highest, but the more tokens you stake, the cheaper it is to downvote you. Votes cost tokens, which makes the system sybil resistant. Upvotes stake more tokens in the contract. The cost to downvote is sent directly back to the person being voted on.
This allows for an intuitive and simple interface, similar to Reddit, with a transparent economic algorithm that provably benefits the community who uses it.
This entry was coauthored by Andy Tudhope.

title: First-Price Auction
description: An auction, typically with a sealed-bid, in which the auction winner pays their bid (and nobody else pays).

title: Flash Loan
description: A type of loan that allows borrowers to borrow and repay funds within a single transaction, without the need for collateral.

title: Fractionalized NFT
description: An NFT divided into multiple pieces, allowing for fractional ownership of the original token.
details: The original NFT gets locked in a smart contract, which creates a predetermined number of fungible tokens, each representing a piece of the NFT.

title: Fungible Transferable Token
description: A token that can be freely traded or transferred between accounts.

title: Futarchy
description: Combines voting with prediction markets to decide which policies will best achieve success metrics.
details:
Futarchy combines democratic value-setting with market-based decision-making. Participants vote on key metrics to define success, such as GDP growth or healthcare improvements. Once these metrics are established, prediction markets are created for various policy proposals to achieve these metrics. Participants in these markets buy and sell shares based on their predictions of the success of each policy. The price of each policy's shares reflects the collective belief in its effectiveness. The policy with the highest market price is then implemented, as it is predicted to achieve the best outcome according to the selected metrics.
Economist Robin Hanson proposed the concept of futarchy in 2000 in the context of representative democracies, where elected officials manage the implementation of policies and measure success metrics. In 2014, Vitalik Buterin extended Hanson’s conceptualization to a decentralized context where smart contracts would automatically enforce the link between prediction market outcomes and policy execution.
Advantages & Applications
Wisdom of Crowds: Leverages collective intelligence and market efficiency for more informed policy decisions.
Improved Decision-Making: Can enhance the speed of complex decisions and rewards accurate predictions and expertise, potentially leading to better decision-making.
Nuanced Preference Expression: Allows for more detailed expression of preferences and beliefs compared to simple voting systems.
Limitations & Risks
Oversimplification of Complex Values: Relying on a single metric to guide policy decisions can oversimplify the multifaceted nature of human values and the complex impacts of different policies.
Short-term Bias: Prediction markets might favor short-term outcomes over long-term benefits that are harder to quantify or predict.
Questionable Market Efficiency: Potentially requires the organization to seed liquidity for each decision it needs to make, which could prove expensive for the long tail of decisions.
Market Manipulation: Lack of liquidity in the prediction market for each decision could make it subject to manipulation by well-capitalized actors.
Design Considerations
Metric Selection: Carefully choose success metrics that align with long-term goals and resist gaming.
Robust Prediction Markets & Outcome Verification: Ensure the prediction markets are robust, transparent, and resistant to manipulation. Guarantee that the process for verifying policy outcomes is transparent and reliable.
Liquidity Provision: Develop strategies to ensure sufficient liquidity in the prediction markets. This might include incentivizing market makers or providing initial liquidity to jumpstart the markets.

resources.resource: Futarchy: Vote Values, But Bet Beliefs (Robin Hanson)
Futarchy and Governance: Prediction Markets Meet DAOs on Solana (Helius)

example_details:
Platform to create, manage, and participate in futarchy DAOs. The MetaDAO system uses prediction markets to determine the potential impact of proposals on the value of a DAO’s token, determining decisions based on market expectations. MetaDAO has three core components:
Conditional Vault: Manages conditional tokens that enable speculation on proposal outcomes, supporting a dual-token system for event-based redemption, thus allowing reversible trades.
Automated Market Maker: Establishes markets for conditional tokens and integrates a time-weighted average price (TWAP) oracle, crucial for decision-making in the Autocrat program and enhancing market manipulation resistance.
Autocrat: Coordinates the futarchy system, overseeing proposal processes from initiation to conclusion, with decisions driven by market conditions reflected through the TWAP.

title: Graduated Sanctions
description: Penalties that increase in severity based on the frequency or degree of rule-breaking.
details:
Graduated sanctions start with minor penalties for first-time or minor rule violations. These penalties escalate according to predefined rules based on the frequency, duration, or severity of a participant's non-compliance. This approach discourages participants from rule violations while concurrently providing an opportunity to correct behavior without imposing severe, immediate penalties.
Graduated sanctions can prove crucial in maintaining system stability and integrity. They ensure that violations are met with proportionate penalties, preventing minor offenses from being overly punished while still imposing severe penalties for major or repeated violations.
Key Considerations Designing a system with graduated sanctions requires careful consideration of the escalation scale and the criteria for increasing sanctions. The parameters should be set such that they deter non-compliance while still being fair and not discouraging participation. The system must be transparent so that participants understand the consequences of their actions. Moreover, graduated sanctions should be combined with other mechanism design primitives to ensure system health and integrity. For instance, alongside graduated sanctions, it could be beneficial to implement rewards for compliance and mechanisms to restore participants who have faced sanctions once they rectify their non-compliant behavior.

example_details:
Ethereum 2.0 uses a system of graduated sanctions to penalize validators that violate protocol rules or stay inactive. These mechanisms help maintain the integrity of the network and incentivize participant activity and adherence to protocol.
Slashing
Validators face slashing when they violate specific rules related to the Casper FFG and LMD GHOST consensus mechanisms, such as making conflicting attestations or block proposals. This violation could be seen as potential attempts to attack the network.
Upon violating the rules, validators are "slashed" resulting in a significant loss of stake and their removal from the network. The severity of the penalty is correlated to the extent of the violation.
Initial Penalty: Upon validation of the offense, validators face an immediate deduction from their balance (1/32 of the effective balance, capped at 1 ETH). Alongside, the validator is queued for exit, with withdrawal only possible approximately 36 days later. This initial penalty discourages any form of self-slashing.
Correlation Penalty: After half of the withdrawal period (18 days post-slashing), a second penalty applies. It correlates with the total amount of stake slashed over 36 days around the validator's slashing. This adjustment means isolated incidents receive lighter penalties, while coordinated attacks leading to mass slashing face severe punishment.
Source: https://eth2book.info/capella/part2/incentives/slashing
Inactivity Leak
The inactivity leak kicks in when the beacon chain, responsible for finalizing transactions, fails due to large numbers of validators being non-participatory or offline.
This triggers two key actions: validators do not receive rewards for attesting to blocks, and non-participating validators start incurring penalties. These penalties are not static; they escalate based on the frequency and duration of a validator's inactivity, embodying the principle of graduated sanctions.
The escalating penalty system serves a dual purpose. Firstly, it deters non-participation by imposing a cost on inactivity. Secondly, it allows the network to recover in the event of large-scale validator failure. As penalties increase, the influence of non-participating validators decreases, enabling active validators to regain control, finalize transactions, and return the network to normal operations.
Source: https://eth2book.info/capella/part2/incentives/inactivity
Both slashing and inactivity leak mechanisms are examples of graduated sanctions in Ethereum 2.0. They ensure validators' adherence to protocol rules and maintain the network's overall health, mitigating the risks of potential attacks or extended inactivity. Moreover, they function as powerful deterrents against non-compliance, thereby fostering an environment of active participation and adherence to rules.

title: Guild Kick
description: Process for removing a DAO member through a proposal that allows the removed member to redeem their funds based on the number of DAO units that the member was holding. Similar to Rage Quit but initialized through a proposal voted on by other members, rather than through unilateral action of the member themselves.

title: Harberger Tax
description: Harberger taxes are a form of taxation on private goods, such as houses, domain names, luxury cars, and NFTs, that incentivize owners to sell or rent unused assets.
details: The item is continuously set on auction, allowing anyone to buy it at any time. The owner can set the selling price, but a recurring tax, based on a percentage of the selling price, is applied. This tax encourages owners to set an optimal selling price, as setting it too high results in higher taxes and no buyers, while setting it too low leads to lower taxes but a higher likelihood of the item being purchased by someone who values it more or believes they can resell it.
