title: Holographic Consensus
description: A governance mechanism that allows for local decisions that represent the interests of a global group.

title: Impact Certificates
description: A digital certificate that represents a measurable positive social or environmental impact. It can be traded, sold, or donated, allowing investors and philanthropists to support projects that align with their values and earn returns from the positive outcomes generated by these projects.

resources.resource: Hypercerts: A new primitive for funding public goods

title: Incentivized Peer Review
description: A mechanism that rewards individuals for reviewing and validating particular content or products within a particular ecosystem.

example_details:
The Yuma consensus algorithm addresses the challenge of diverging viewpoints and potential manipulation by bad actor validators in the Bittensor network.
In Yuma Consensus, validators earn rewards for producing evaluations of the value created by miners that align with the subjective evaluations of other validators. This alignment is weighted by stake, meaning validators who have more at stake in the network (demonstrated through their locked TAO tokens) have a greater influence on the consensus. This setup encourages validators to remain honest and in agreement with the network consensus to earn dividends.
"Yuma consensus rewards validators with dividends for producing evaluations of miner-value which are in agreement with the subjective evaluations produced by other validators weighted by stake, TAO which has been locked into Bittensor's incentive mechanism and attached to a validator."

Lakat is a protocol that allows users with an Ethereum key-pair to publish content in a continuous integration fashion, using the Ethereum ecosystem as a storage anchor and through tokens that track activity.
Lakat leverages a "proof of peer review" process where contributors to a branch (similar to journal editors) engage in reviewing submissions. The protocol adds new blocks to branches based on these peer reviews, creating a blockchain-like structure where blocks consist of reviewed changes rather than transactions. This process is backed by a consensus mechanism called Lignification, which is localized to branch contributors and operates in tandem with the open review process.

title: Incentivized Voting
description: Financial incentives for individual voters and/or delegates to participate in governance.

title: Instant Governance
description: Token-holders stake on values for each governance parameter and the resulting value is adjusted in real-time based on the stake-weighted median.

title: Liquid Democracy
description: A hybrid system that allows participants to directly vote on issues or delegate their votes to trusted delegate.

title: Liquidity Bonds
description: Allows users to exchange liquidity pool (LP) tokens for discounted protocol tokens, usually with a lock-up.
details:
The protocol effectively sells its tokens at a discount in exchange for users providing liquidity to their token, resulting in more alignment between the liquidity providers and the intentions of the project.
For the protocol this bonding mechanism provides a way to generate liquidity and earnings via Protocol-owned Liquidity. For users it provides a way to effectively buy tokens at a discounted rate, albeit while taking on more risk.

resources.resource: Explaining the (3, 3) Meme, Bonding, and Stablecoins

example_details:
Bonding starts by adding liquidity to the OLAS-ETH Uniswap pool, and then trading the LP tokens for discounted OLAS on the bonding page of the Olas tokenomics website. After a vesting period (7 days), the user can claim the full OLAS amount.
How it works:
Browse for bonding products
Get LP tokens on Uniswap
Bond LP tokens via app
Wait for bond to mature, then claim discounted OLAS
In order to moderate inflation of OLAS, the protocol dynamically adjusts bonding emissions in response to the volume of the protocol's dev rewards mechanism. This is designed to ensure that liquidity incentives increase and decrease in proportion to ecosystem activity.

title: Liquidity Bootstrapping Pool (LBP)
description: A mechanism that allows for the gradual release of a particular token into a liquidity pool, allowing for price discovery and the creation of a market.

title: Liquidity Mining
description: Rewarding users who provide liquidity to particular token pools.
details: Initially pioneered by Synthetix in 2019 to incentivize liquidity for their synthetic ETH product. Users who staked sETH/ETH liquidity pool (LP) tokens from Uniswap into a staking contract earned SNX tokens (Synthetix's native token) in proportion to their share of the total LP tokens staked.

resources.resource: Liquidity Mining: The Good, The Bad, The Ugly
How to Implement a Stake and Reward Contract in Solidity

example_details: A Constant Function Market Maker (CFMM) implementation which became popular for providing low-fees and low-slippage in stablecoin pools (e.g. DAI - USDC). It introduced a novel “amplification coefficient” in its pricing function which allows for low-slippage. It uses a combination of constant product and constant sum functions to achieve this. For more information check out: Whitepaper.

The biggest decentralized exchange (DEX) by volume. It is primarily known for pioneering Constant Product Market Makers (CPMM), a specific class of AMM that uses the constant product formula to price assets in a pool. The formula is $x*y = k$, where $x$ and $y$ are the amount of each token held in the pool, respectively, and $k$ is a constant. The latest version is Uniswap V3, which introduced methods to improve capital efficiency.

title: Lottery
description: Awarding prizes to randomly selected participants.
details: Lotteries, as mechanisms, have existed for centuries and span various cultures. Their fundamental attraction lies in the random chance of receiving a disproportionately large reward compared to the initial investment.

example_details:
"No loss lottery" where users deposit funds into a group pool that periodically pays out pooled interest to randomly selected winners.
The pool earns interest from DeFi protocols such as Compound and Aave. Depositors can always withdraw 100% of their principal. In this way, participants just risk the opportunity cost of the interest on their deposit and not the deposit itself.
This concept derives from the prize-linked savings account.

The project creates a crowdfunding campaign and rallies supporters to donate.
During the campaign, the project hosts multiple lucky draws - but the winners do not recieve prizes immediately.
If the campaign reaches the target, the project receives funding and winners receive prizes. If not, all donors get a full refund.

title: Minimum Anti-Collusion Infrastructure
description: Minimum Anti-Collusion Infrastructure (MACI) is a solution that uses zero-knowledge proofs to make blockchain voting, such as quadratic funding mechanisms, resistant to bribery and collusion.
details:
MACI consists of smart contracts and scripts that allow a central administrator, called a coordinator, to aggregate votes and tally results without revealing how each individual voted. This ensures the integrity of the voting process and reduces the effectiveness of collusion schemes.
MACI works by having users register their public keys in a smart contract and cast votes as encrypted messages. The coordinator processes all messages after the voting period ends, tallies the votes, and verifies the results on-chain. Zero-knowledge proofs are used to guarantee the correctness of computation, making it impossible for the coordinator to incorrectly process votes and tally results.
While MACI requires trusting the coordinator not to collude or bribe voters, it offers a powerful tool for ensuring the sanctity of on-chain voting when the coordinator remains honest. This makes it popular among applications that rely heavily on the integrity of individual voting choices, such as quadratic funding mechanisms.

title: Multisend
description: Sending tokens to multiple recipients in a single transaction.

title: Multistakeholder Governance
description: Representing the distinct interests of different stakeholders in the governance mechanics of a given system. This approach aims to incorporate a diverse range of perspectives, ensuring a more inclusive and resilient decision-making process.
details:
In a multi-stakeholder governance system, decision-making authority is distributed among different groups or entities that have a vested interest in the outcomes. These stakeholders may include users, investors, developers, community members, and other relevant parties. Each stakeholder group typically has a defined set of rights, responsibilities, and voting power.
Decisions can be made through various on-chain and off-chain mechanisms such as voting, consensus-building, or even delegation. Depending on the specific structure, some stakeholders may have more influence than others based on factors like ownership stakes, contributions to the project, or expertise in relevant domains.
Multi-stakeholder governance draws upon democratic principles and social choice theory. It emphasizes the importance of representation and participation in decision-making processes. Additionally, it aligns with the principles of decentralization and decentralization-resistant systems often seen in blockchain and distributed ledger technologies.
Multi-stakeholder governance takes various forms, each tailored to the unique dynamics of the system it governs. A notable example is bicameral governance, mirroring the structure of many democratic legislative systems, where decision-making is split across two distinct chambers representing different stakeholder groups. This ensures a more balanced and representative decision-making process. Other models include consensus-based governance, where decisions require agreement from all stakeholders, emphasizing collaboration but potentially slowing the process. Rotational governance models circulate decision-making roles among stakeholder groups, ensuring dynamic and diverse leadership. Some systems adopt hybrid approaches, combining direct democratic elements with representative structures, allowing for direct stakeholder votes on critical issues while delegating routine decisions to elected bodies.
Advantages & Applications
Inclusivity and Representation: Multi-stakeholder governance ensures that a broad spectrum of interests is considered, leading to decisions that better reflect the collective will of the stakeholders.
Resilience and Adaptability: This mechanism promotes adaptability to changing circumstances, as it can incorporate diverse perspectives and expertise.
Reduced Centralization: It mitigates the risk of decision-making becoming concentrated in the hands of a few.
Limitations & Risks
Complexity: Coordinating multiple stakeholders with differing interests can lead to slower decision-making processes, and in some cases, deadlock.
Potential for Conflicts: Conflicts of interest among stakeholders may arise, necessitating robust conflict resolution mechanisms.
Challenges in Implementation: Designing effective multi-stakeholder governance systems requires careful consideration of stakeholder categories, rights, and voting mechanisms.
Key Considerations
Clear Definition of Stakeholder Categories: Define and categorize stakeholders based on relevant criteria, such as ownership, contribution, or expertise.
Balancing Influence: Determine the weight of each stakeholder's vote or influence based on their level of contribution and alignment with the project's goals.
Conflict Resolution Mechanisms: Establish procedures for resolving disputes or conflicts that may arise among stakeholders.
Transparency and Accountability: Implement mechanisms for transparent communication, reporting, and accountability to ensure trust among stakeholders.
This entry was coauthored by PhilH.

example_details: Proposed governance change that would give stETH holders the ability veto proposals submitted by LDO holders. The dual-governance setup allows stakers of ETH (the protocol's users) to block any adversarial change by LDO holders (the protocol's owners).
The Optimism Collective is governed by a two-house system. The Token House is made up of OP holders and their delegates, and the Citizens’ House is a one-person-one-vote system based on reputation.

title: Mutual Credit
description: Credit that members can issue to each other based on mutual trust, rather than using traditional forms of collateral.

resources.resource: Liquidity-Saving through Obligation-Clearing and Mutual Credit

example_details:
Honour is a peer-to-peer social credit system that utilizes non-transferable tokens called HON to represent reputation and mutual credit between users. It aims to redefine money as a measure of obligation rather than wealth.
Mechanisms
1. Non-Transferable Token (HON)
HON tokens are created when a user accepts another user's proposal.
These tokens are non-transferable, making them an individual liability rather than an asset.
The number of HON tokens held by an individual serves as a measure of their reputation but also their level of obligation in the system.
2. Mutual Credit
Transactions in the system are consensual and aim to create social bonds.
Money (in the form of HON tokens) is created as needed and is forgiven when it's no longer required.
Users can forgive as much HON as they currently hold, facilitating a self-regulating mutual credit system.
Implications
Honour effectively blends non-transferable tokens and mutual credit to create a unique social credit system. It challenges traditional notions of money and value, focusing on community engagement and mutual obligations.
Asset vs Liability: Unlike traditional currencies, holding HON signifies an individual's obligations rather than wealth.
Community Building: The system encourages users to be a bit indebted to each other, creating stronger social bonds.
Consensual Transactions: All transactions are based on mutual agreement, fostering trust within the community.
Dynamic Money Creation: Money is created or forgiven as needed, aligning closely with actual social needs rather than market forces.

title: Mutual Insurance
description: A cooperative insurance model where members pool resources to provide coverage against losses.

title: NFT Drop
description: A method of distributing non-fungible tokens (NFTs) through a random or selective process.

title: Non-Fungible Token (NFT)
description: A unique and indivisible token that represents digital ownership.

title: Non-Transferable NFT
description: A non-transferable, non-fungible token (NFT), typically used to represent a digital badge or achievement within a particular context.

title: Non-Transferable Token
description: A non-transferable, fungible token, typically used to represent a user's reputation within a particular context.

example_details:
Honour is a peer-to-peer social credit system that utilizes non-transferable tokens called HON to represent reputation and mutual credit between users. It aims to redefine money as a measure of obligation rather than wealth.
Mechanisms
1. Non-Transferable Token (HON)
HON tokens are created when a user accepts another user's proposal.
These tokens are non-transferable, making them an individual liability rather than an asset.
The number of HON tokens held by an individual serves as a measure of their reputation but also their level of obligation in the system.
2. Mutual Credit
Transactions in the system are consensual and aim to create social bonds.
Money (in the form of HON tokens) is created as needed and is forgiven when it's no longer required.
Users can forgive as much HON as they currently hold, facilitating a self-regulating mutual credit system.

title: Optimistic Governance
description: Proposals default to passing unless there is enough resistance. Participants vote against the options they dislike, rather than for the options they prefer.
details: The concept originates from sociocracy, a governance model developed by Gerard Endenburg in the Netherlands in the 1970s. Endenburg, an engineer, applied systems thinking to organizational governance, inspired by his Quaker schooling and the work of Kees Boeke. Sociocracy aims for a harmonious balance between autonomy and collaboration, focusing on the collective aim and efficient operations. It uses feedback loops and structured decision-making processes to ensure all voices are heard without requiring unanimous agreement. Decisions are made when there is no "reasoned objection." This means a proposal is accepted as long as no one presents a substantial reason why it should not proceed. This method emphasizes objection management rather than seeking complete agreement.

title: Oracle
description: Information source that provides external data to smart contracts, bridging the gap between on-chain and off-chain systems.
details:
Since smart contracts are designed to be deterministic and self-executing, they cannot access external (off-chain) data directly. Oracles solve this problem by acting as intermediaries, feeding verified data to smart contracts, which is essential for various use cases like financial services, supply chain management, and prediction markets.
Oracles can be classified into several types, including software oracles (accessing online data sources), hardware oracles (interacting with physical devices), and human oracles (relying on human input). They can also be centralized or decentralized, with the latter offering higher levels of trust and security.

title: Osmotic Funding
description: Voters signal budgeting preferences by staking tokens on projects. The rate at which each project is funded is determined by the staked amount and the available funds. The rate variations are smoothed over time to avoid high rate variations and offer stability to the projects.

title: Over-the-Counter (OTC) Transaction
description: Direct exchange of assets between two parties without using a public exchange.
details: OTC transactions involve the direct transfer of digital assets between two parties based on mutually agreed terms. These assets can include fungible tokens, including stablecoins, as well as non-fungible tokens (NFTs). The process usually involves negotiation over the asset type, quantity, and price, often facilitated by OTC desks or platforms that specialize in matching buyers with sellers. Once an agreement is reached, the OTC smart contract facilitates trustless swapping of assets between the parties.

title: Pairwise
description: A budgeting process where options are presented in pairs, and participants choose their preferred option from each pair. The formula distributes funding by computing the preferences over all pairwise comparisons.

title: Pass/Fail Voting
description: A simple binary voting system where participants can only choose between "yes" or "no".

title: Patronage-Based Token Earnings
description: A mechanism where token holders earn rewards in proportion to their usage of a platform or provision of service to the platform.

title: Payment Splitter
description: Divides incoming payments among multiple recipients according to hardcoded or dynamic ownership percentages.
details: Splitters can be used in situations such as profit-sharing, contributor payments, or royalties for creative works.

example_details: GHST is sold for DAI on a bonding curve gated to users who have been approved through a centralized KYC process. GHST is a currency token that users can spend on portals and wearables. Spent GHST is split between users via rarity farming, the developer team, and the community DAO, and a portion is burned, which increases the bonding curve price.

Each profile has a personal token bonding curve (i.e., “creator coin”) tied to their reputation that any user can buy and sell. Profiles can share revenue with their token holders by selling goods and access to services that share revenue with the curve, thereby increasing the token redemption price. Creator coins are designed to be naturally scarce, typically ranging from 100 to 1,500 coins per profile. As more people buy a creator's coins, the price increases at an accelerating rate, following a quadratic bonding curve formula.

title: Personhood
description: Related to SSI/DID but with emphasis on sybil resistance. This mechanism aims to prevent any one human from having multiple identities.

example_details: A social identity network that utilizes WoT for creating a secure and scalable identity system.

title: Points
description: Measures individual contributions or participation and allocates rewards proportionally to the systems’ overall contributions over a defined period, after which they can be converted to tangible rewards.
details:
Points function as a flexible accounting system for tracking and rewarding user participation and contributions in a dynamic environment. Unlike simple token rewards, points create a relative measure where the system’s total activity determines each point’s value during a given epoch. The underlying smart contracts manage point issuance, valuation, and redemption, often integrating with external data sources or oracles to determine contribution value and system activity levels. The mechanism’s incentive structure adapts to the level of participation: In periods of low overall contribution, the potential value of each point increases, encouraging more participants to engage. Conversely, as participation surges, the relative value of each point decreases, naturally moderating excessive contributions. This self-balancing feature helps maintain system equilibrium and ensures that rewards remain proportional to the impact of individual contributions relative to the whole. Points systems often incorporate immediate feedback through point accrual and delayed gratification in reward distribution to encourage sustained engagement.
The concept of points can be traced back to mining pools for Proof of Work and Proof of Stake blockchains like Bitcoin and Ethereum. Off-chain mining pools treat the compute or capital provided by validators as ‘points’ towards their share of each block reward. In 2021, projects like Coordinape and Praise emerged to help decentralized communities track and reward user contributions to DAOs through points over repeating epochs. Points gained significant traction in 2023 with the launch of point programs by Blast and Eigenlayer, which drove rapid user adoption. This marked a shift from early blockchain systems that primarily used tokens with financial value to incentivize participation. Since then, points systems have been increasingly adopted in blockchain applications, including social media platforms like friend.tech and wallets like Rabby.
Advantages & Applications
Adaptive Incentivization: Points systems can automatically adjust incentives based on participation levels, maintaining an optimal balance of engagement.
Fairness in Reward Distribution: By tying rewards to relative contribution, points ensure that rewards are distributed proportionally to effort and impact.
Gamification: Accumulating points can tap into users’ competitive instincts, driving increased participation and engagement.
Versatility: Points can be applied across various contexts, from staking or compute contributions to usage incentives and development rewards.
Limitations & Risks
Value Uncertainty: Participants may be discouraged by the inability to predict the exact value of their points at the time of contribution.
Potential for Gaming: Without proper safeguards, users might find ways to accumulate points without providing genuine value to the system.
Reward Delay: The time lag between point accumulation and reward distribution might reduce the immediate incentive for participation.
Design Considerations
Epoch Duration: Balance between providing frequent feedback (shorter epochs) and capturing meaningful contribution patterns (longer epochs).
Point Calculation Algorithm: Design a robust algorithm that accurately reflects the desired type and quality of contributions.
Transparency vs. Anti-Gaming: Determine how much information about the current state of points and participation is revealed, balancing transparency with the need to prevent strategic manipulation.
Reward Pool Allocation: Decide whether to fix the total rewards per epoch or allow it to fluctuate based on overall participation levels or market conditions.
Carryover Mechanics: Consider whether and how to allow points to carry over between epochs, impacting long-term engagement patterns.
Diminishing Returns: Implement mechanisms to prevent dominance by a small group of power users, such as diminishing point returns for repeated actions.

resources.resource: Beyond Tokens: The Era of Onchain Points (Graeme)
Pointenomics 101: Understanding the New Language of Crypto Incentives (Tradedog Research)

example_details: Uses “Restaked Points” as a measure of staking participation. These points are calculated based on the time-integrated amount staked in units of ETH · hours, providing a way to quantify and reward user engagement in the protocol.

Released a points program before their token launch to incentivize its browser extension and desktop app usage. Users can earn daily points for referring friends, swapping, and using Rabby’s gas top-up feature. The program also offers bonus points to attract users from other platforms, such as those who have used Metamask Swap.

Implemented a points system before their token launch to incentivize early user engagement and activity. Users could earn points through various activities on the platform like higher trading volumes or successful referrals. Points were calculated weekly and distributed every Friday. When the V2 launched, a portion of the project’s token supply was airdropped to points earners.

Implements a decentralized reward distribution system using “GIVE” tokens. During each epoch (typically one week to one month), circle members receive 100 GIVE tokens to allocate to other contributors based on their perceived value. At the epoch’s end, each contributor receives a share of the total allocated rewards budget based on the proportion of GIVE tokens they received.

Utilizes a point system to drive user engagement and liquidity. Blast Points can be earned primarily by bridging assets to the Blast mainnet, inviting friends to participate, and trading tokens. The amount of Blast Points earned is proportional to the wallet balance of bridged assets, with point earnings growing over time due to Blast’s native yield generation. Users can earn point “boosts” through referrals, secondary referrals, and tiered trading volumes. This system encourages direct participation and network growth, contributing to Blast’s rapid adoption and high Total Value Locked (TVL).

Community intelligence system where members acknowledge and reward each other's contributions through interactions with a chatbot. Contributions are quantified and assigned a praise score, which can be used for monetary or non-monetary rewards.

title: Prediction Market
description: Allow users to trade on future event outcomes, using market prices to reflect each outcome's probability. Participants stake tokens on their predictions, and markets are resolved when event outcomes are verified.

title: Private Voting
description: A form of voting that allows participants to keep their votes private, providing a layer of anonymity.

title: Proposal Inverter
description: Proposal can receive funding from multiple sources rather than just one.
details: These sources pool their funds together, and the money is disbursed to the project executor in portions as they achieve predefined milestones. This approach encourages collaboration among different funding entities and ensures that the project meets certain objectives before receiving the complete funding. This mechanism can be useful in promoting accountability, fostering cooperation among funders, and reducing the risk of funding unsuccessful projects.

resources.resource: Proposal Inverter-The next stage in DAO2DAO Coordination

title: Protection Market
description: Insures against losses from holding specific assets or using particular protocols by charging a fee proportional to the risk and amount being protected.

title: Protocol-Owned Liquidity
description: Liquidity Pool tokens owned by the protocol itself. This allows the protocol to provide a floor of liquidity for its protocol while also allowing it to capture some of the transaction fees from the liquidity pool.

title: Quadratic Attention Payments
description: An advertising mechanism that uses quadratic voting to enhance ad relevance, user engagement, and revenue distribution among stakeholders.
details:
First, advertisers pool funds to run their campaigns on a given platform. Users then upvote or downvote ads based on intensity of preference using a set number of "voting credits". These votes are weighted quadratically in order to arrive at a relative set of values that represents the popularity of each ad. Advertisers are then reimbursed based on the sum of the degrees of preference, calculated as a quadratic weighting of the aggregated upvotes minus downvotes. The ad also gets extended or reduced according to this factor.
The the initial idea was proposed by Vitalik Buterin in his essay on Quadratic Payments. In it, he argues that public ads, as a subsector of public goods, are a non-optimal good as the public does not have an efficient way to coordinate in selecting the ads that interest them.
Advantages & Applications
Improved Relevance & Engagement: Users see more ads that interest them.
Efficient Pricing: The reimbursement feature allows for dynamic pricing, aligning the actual cost incurred by advertisers more closely with the ad's effectiveness and user engagement.
Applicability: Can be integrated into existing advertising platforms, like Brave Ads, as well as decentralized social networks like Lens or Farcaster.
Limitations & Risks
Sybil Attacks: The system is vulnerable to users creating multiple accounts to manipulate voting.
Complexity: Implementing a secure and fair quadratic voting system is technically challenging.
Privacy Risks: Though the mechanism aims for user- and privacy-centricity, implementing zero-knowledge proofs for secure voting can be difficult.
Key Considerations
Vote Verification vs. Privacy: Balance is needed between verifying votes to prevent Sybil attacks and maintaining user privacy.
Campaign Cost Calculation: Advertisers must understand the formula for reimbursement based on downvotes and quadratic fees.
Ad Duration Variance: The mechanism modifies ad durations based on the sum of user preferences, requiring careful monitoring.
This entry was coauthored by Bernardo Vicente.

resources.resource: A Tax on the Purchase of Human Attention and Political Power

example_details: In this proof of concept, QAP is used to accurately value user engagement by giving power to the users to curate their own advertising experience. By integrating with Brave's existing attention-tracking features, QAP introduces a quadratic voting scheme where users vote for ads they prefer. The resulting quadratic fees become a revenue stream for advertisers and act as an incentive for creating higher-quality, more relevant ads. This aims for an ecosystem where users are exposed to fewer but more personalized ads, publishers and advertisers gain enhanced targeting insights, and revenue is more equitably distributed among all stakeholders.

title: Quadratic Funding
description: Quadratic funding is a donation-matching scheme that prioritizes projects based on the number of people who contributed rather than just the amount contributed. The share of the matching pool that each project receives is based on the square root of each contribution. This reduces the power of large donors to influence the matching of funds.

title: Quadratic Voting
description: A voting mechanism where participants can allocate a limited number of voting "points" to different options, with the number of points allocated being proportional to the square root of the number of points.

title: Quest
description: A gamified process where participants are incentivized to complete tasks or solve problems.

title: Quorum
description: Minimum level of participation required for a decision to be valid

title: Rage Quit
description: Participants can withdraw their stake or membership if they disagree with a decision made by the group.

title: Ranked Choice Voting
description: A voting system where participants rank the available options in order of preference.

title: Redeemable NFT
description: NFT that is redeemable for a discrete good.

title: Referral Incentives
description: A mechanism where participants earn rewards for bringing in new users.

title: Rentable NFT
description: An NFT that can be rented out to others for a fee.

title: Research Object
description: A digital object that encapsulates data, code, and other assets related to a specific research project.

title: Reversible ICO
description: Token sale in which committed funds are used to buy tokens gradually, giving individual purchasers the possibility of partially reversing their purchase within a fixed time window.
details:
The Reversible ICO is seperated in two phases, a commit phase and a buy phase.
In the commit phase everyone can reserve tokens and return those reserved tokens if they change their mind, without having bought anything. The participant's tokens are locked and the project has no access to the funds.
In the buy phase committed funds gradually buy the tokens. Participants can return the portion of locked tokens to withdraw their corresponding funds at any time.
Token price also increases over time according to a fixed curve.

title: Royalty Fee
description: Creator earns a percentage of revenue for each subsequent transaction involving their work.

title: Shareable NFT
description: A non-fungible token (NFT) that can be shared or split among multiple users.

title: Single Choice Voting
description: A simple voting system in which participants choose one option from a list of choices.

title: Slashing
description: A punitive measure where a network participant loses a portion or all of their staked assets for not adhering to the protocol rules.
details:
Slashing is used to deter and manage potential threats or malicious behavior by network participants. Participants stake their assets as a form of commitment. If they fail to adhere to the protocol rules, they risk losing a portion or all of their staked assets.
The concept of slashing is rooted in game theory, specifically the concept of punishment in repeated games. By introducing a cost for malicious actions, it enforces honesty and active participation in the network. 
Advantages & Applications Slashing is beneficial in maintaining network security and integrity. Slashing has found significant applications in Proof of Stake (PoS) blockchain networks like Ethereum 2.0 and Cosmos, where it is used to penalize validators who propose conflicting blocks, double signing, and downtime. It can also be useful in truth games or the oracle problem, where a distributed set of actors needs to reach consensus on an observable fact.
Limitations & Risks
Wrongful Slashing: The major drawback is the potential for wrongful slashing due to bugs, network issues or honest mistakes. This can lead to centralization if smaller participants cannot afford the risk of being slashed.
Barrier to Entry: Requiring participants to stake assets can pose a barrier to entry.
Key Considerations
Designers should carefully set the slashing conditions and penalties, making sure to differentiate between intentional malicious behavior and honest mistakes or unforeseen issues.
Non-financial assets or tokens may also be used as slashing collateral, such as non-transferable reputation points or membership badges (see Non-Transferable Token).

example_details:
The Gitcoin Slashing Engine is a proof of concept designed by Mechanism Institute to identify and penalize sybil accounts misusing Gitcoin passports to pose as unique humans. The engine aims to provide a solution to coordination games that rely on subjective data submitted by different parties. It ensures that where there is significant agreement, action can be taken automatically and transparently, while also ensuring that the extent of overlap required can be updated and recalibrated based on feedback from the broader community.
The Slashing Engine operates through a system of staking and flagging. Users can stake any amount of GTC (Gitcoin's native token). If the staked amount exceeds a certain threshold set by the DAO, the user becomes a "guardian". There is no limit on the number of guardians, and the DAO can adjust the staking threshold according to their judgment.
Guardians have the power to flag any account as a sybil (fraudulent) account. The amount staked by the guardian is recorded as the amountCommitted to the claim that the flagged account is a sybil. The amountCommitted must exceed a specific threshold before it can be unstaked in the passport contract. This threshold is set by the DAO, calculated as the highest amount staked by any guardian multiplied by a CONFIDENCE factor set by the DAO. This ensures that it always requires more than one guardian to cause any account flagged as a sybil to be slashed.
Guardians can also vote to slash other guardians if they are behaving maliciously (i.e., flagging accounts as sybils who are not). If the number of guardians voting on one guardian to be slashed exceeds a threshold set by the DAO, that guardian is slashed.

title: Smart Property
description: Using smart contracts to manage the ownership and control of physical assets.
details: Through these contracts, the control of keys for operating the property is automatically assigned to the rightful owner according to the contract terms. A practical example is a smart lock that only unlocks for the verified owner, preventing theft and unauthorized use. Smart property offers various benefits, such as simplifying ownership verification, reducing fraud, lowering mediation fees, and enabling transactions that might not have been possible otherwise. Additionally, it supports online lending using smart property as collateral, which can make credit more affordable and competitive.

title: Social Graph
description: A graphical representation of individuals and their relationships

title: Sortition
description: A process where a randomly selected group of individuals make a decision on a dispute or issue. Selection probability could be equal for every participant or weighted by a number of different factors, such as tokens staked or square root of tokens staked.

title: Stakedrop
description: A method for distributing tokens to participants who commit and "lock up" their existing tokens for a specified period. It serves as a means to bootstrap a network, incentivize early adopters, and secure initial funding for a project.
details:
In a lockdrop, participants lock up a certain amount of an existing cryptocurrency or token in a smart contract for a predetermined period. This locked amount serves as collateral or commitment, demonstrating the participant's interest in the new project or network. At the end of the lock-up period, participants receive a proportionate amount of the new tokens being distributed.
The length of the lock-up period and the ratio of new tokens received typically vary based on the specific design of the lockdrop. Projects may choose to have different tiers or periods, allowing participants to choose their level of commitment.
Lockdrop draws on concepts from Delegated Proof-of-Stake (DPoS) and Time-Locked Tokens. It leverages the idea of staking and commitment to secure a network, while also involving the distribution of new tokens.
Advantages & Applications
Network Security: Lockdrop encourages participants to commit to the new network, which can enhance security and participation in the early stages.
Token Distribution: It provides a fair and decentralized method for distributing tokens to a wide range of participants, potentially avoiding issues of centralization.
Incentivizing Early Adopters: Participants who believe in the project's potential are incentivized to lock up their assets, providing an initial user base and network effect.
Limitations & Risks
Loss of Liquidity: Participants lose access to their locked assets for the duration of the lock-up period, which can be a downside for those who need liquidity.
Uncertain Future Value: The value of the new tokens received after the lock-up period is uncertain and can be influenced by various market factors.
Complexity: Designing an effective lockdrop mechanism requires careful consideration of parameters like lock-up period, rewards distribution, and participant eligibility.
Key Considerations
Lock-up Period: Define the duration participants must commit their tokens. Consider offering different tiers for varying commitment levels.
Rewards Ratio: Determine the ratio at which new tokens will be distributed in exchange for locked assets.
Eligibility Criteria: Clearly specify which tokens are eligible for the lockdrop, as well as any requirements for participation.
Transparency and Trustlessness: Implement the lockdrop as a smart contract to ensure transparency and eliminate the need for intermediaries.
This entry was coauthored by PhilH.

example_details: Combination of lockdrop distribution with a price-discovery process through auctions (Liquidity Bootstrap Auction), proposed by Delphi Labs
Edgeware, a decentralized smart contract platform built on Substrate, utilized a lockdrop mechanism for its token distribution. Participants locked up their ETH or other tokens to receive EDG tokens.

title: Staking Gauges
description: Directing incentives towards different options based on token weighted staking

example_details: A Constant Function Market Maker (CFMM) implementation which became popular for providing low-fees and low-slippage in stablecoin pools (e.g. DAI - USDC). It introduced a novel “amplification coefficient” in its pricing function which allows for low-slippage. It uses a combination of constant product and constant sum functions to achieve this. For more information check out: Whitepaper.

The balancer protocol implements a generalized version of the Constant Mean Market Maker that allows for $n$-token pools (where 2 ≤ $n$ ≤ 50), users-defined weights, and customizable fees. It’s value proposition lies in its customizability which enables the creation of weighted pools, stable pools, and managed pools.

title: Streaming Auction
description: An auction mechanism that allows participants to bid on an item over a set period of time.
details:
Streaming auctions work by allowing market participants to deposit and withdraw tokens from an auction pool. Participants receive a share of reward tokens based on their deposit amount. The exchange rate changes with deposits and withdrawals, and deposits get locked over time. The average exchange rate for each participant depends on when they deposit and withdraw. They receive a Time-Weighted Average Price (TWAP) based on their time in the pool.
Streaming Auctions benefit users by avoiding gas wars, allowing them to commit funds only when they agree with the price, preventing retroactive dilution, eliminating the need to time the market, and guaranteeing allocation. To create a streaming auction, a stream creator specifies variables such as start time, duration, tokens involved, lockup periods, and an optional list of whitelisted participants. Receipt tokens can be issued, which are redeemable for the deposit token at maturity and can be used for various purposes, like collateral or liquidity provision.
Use cases for Streaming Auctions include fair NFT distribution, fixed-duration liquidity mining programs, acquisition of protocol-controlled value, and DAO treasury diversification.

title: Subscription Fee
description: Users pay a recurring fee in exchange for access to a service or content.

title: Subsidized Voting
description: A system in which the transaction cost of voting is automatically covered by the organization.

title: Supply Rebasing
description: A monetary policy where the supply of tokens is adjusted automatically based on market conditions.

title: Swapper
description: Swaps all incoming tokens into a desired output token.

title: Time-Based Booster
description: Staked tokens accumulate boosts over time which award them more rewards and/or governance rights. Boosts are reset whenever tokens are unstaked or transferred.
details: This gives more stake to longer-term participants while giving them the flexibility to exit the system at any time.

title: Time-Bound Funding Round
description: Participants submit proposals within a fixed time period for a fixed amount of capital, which is distributed among top winners based on the voting outcome.

example_details: Contests for communities to make, execute, and reward decisions.

title: Time-bound NFT
description: An NFT that is only valid during a particular time period, and expires after that time.

title: Time-Delay Execution
description: A mechanism that imposes a delay on certain actions to prevent spam, fraud or attacks.

title: Time-Weighted Average Market-Maker (TWAMM)
description: Automated market maker (AMM) that uses time-based weightings to price assets.

title: Time-Weighted Average Price (TWAP)
description: Pricing algorithm that calculates the average price of an asset over a set period of time.

title: Token Abstracted Voting
description: Vote with tokens that are in liquidity pool tokens or being lent to a pool, or are on a different chain.

title: Token Bonding Curve
description: Issues tokens according to an algorithmic price curve as a function of circulating supply, where token price increases as tokens are purchased on the curve and decreases as tokens are sold back to the curve.
details:
Token bonding curves are a dynamic pricing mechanism that uses a mathematical formula to determine token prices based on the circulating supply, unlike traditional tokens with market-driven prices. As more tokens are purchased and minted, the price increases along the predefined curve. Conversely, the price decreases when tokens are sold back to the smart contract and burned.
This type of token creates a direct relationship between supply and price, allowing for continuous liquidity and automated price discovery without relying on traditional order books or market makers. Token bonding curves should not be confused with the more general automated market makers (AMMs) concept. Whereas AMMs typically refer to an algorithmic secondary market (S-AMM) that enables trading between two or more tokens, token bonding curves refer to the case where an AMM serves as the primary token issuing mechanism (P-AMM).
The mechanism originated in 2017, with two key developments occurring in parallel. Bancor introduced “smart tokens” to provide automated liquidity without traditional exchanges. At the same time, Simon de la Rouviere coined the term “bonding curves” and expanded on their potential applications in curation markets.
Variations Token bonding curves can be implemented using various mathematical curves, each impacting the token’s pricing dynamics differently:
Linear Bonding Curve: Price increases linearly with the number of tokens issued. Each additional token costs a fixed amount more than the previous one.
Exponential Bonding Curve: Price increases exponentially as more tokens are purchased, resulting in rapid price escalation.
Polynomial Bonding Curve: Price increases polynomially with the number of tokens issued. For instance, the price could grow quadratically or cubically, making the early tokens significantly cheaper and encouraging early adoption.
Logarithmic Bonding Curve: Price increases sharply initially but slows down as more tokens are issued.
Sigmoid Bonding Curve: Price follows an S-shaped trajectory, starting slow, accelerating rapidly in the middle, then tapering off as token supply increases. This mimics natural growth patterns, balancing early adopter incentives with long-term price stability. The curve’s steepness and inflection point can be adjusted to suit different project lifecycles, making it versatile for various tokenomic models.
Inverse Bonding Curve: Price that decreases with the number of tokens issued initially but increases after reaching a certain supply threshold.
Multi-dimensional Bonding Curve: Allows minting of multiple tokens against a single reserve asset or a single token against multiple reserve assets.
Advantages & Applications
Efficient Price Discovery: Bonding curves provide a continuous and algorithmic approach to price discovery, reflecting real-time supply and demand. This reduces the risk of price manipulation and ensures token prices adjust naturally based on market activity.
Built-in Liquidity: The bonding curve mechanism inherently provides liquidity, allowing users to buy or sell tokens at any time directly through the smart contract. This is particularly advantageous for new projects looking to establish a liquid market without relying on external exchanges.
Continuous Revenue/Fundraising: Projects can use token bonding curves for initial and ongoing fundraising by setting a fee on buys or sells. The continuous pricing model enables a steady inflow of funds as the project grows and attracts more participants, ensuring long-term financial sustainability.
Incentivizing Early Adoption: Early buyers can potentially benefit from price appreciation as more tokens are minted, encouraging early participation.
Limitations & Risks
Price Volatility: The price of token bonding curves can be highly volatile, especially during the early stages when the token supply is low. Large trades can exacerbate this volatility, leading to significant price swings.
Complex Implementation: Designing and implementing a bonding curve requires a deep understanding of mathematical and economic principles. This complexity can be a barrier for developers and users, potentially limiting adoption.
Market Manipulation: Although bonding curves mitigate some forms of manipulation, they are still susceptible to market dynamics and speculative behavior, which can destabilize the token price.
Design Considerations
Curve Design: Each bonding curve type impacts token price dynamics and incentive structures uniquely, shaping the economic behavior and sustainability of the project. Linear curves offer predictable, steady growth; exponential curves heavily reward early participants but risk unsustainable increases; polynomial curves encourage early adoption with controlled long-term growth; logarithmic curves balance rapid initial growth with later stabilization; sigmoid curves mimic natural growth with early acceleration and later deceleration; inverse curves decrease prices initially but increase after a supply threshold; and multi-dimensional curves support complex economic models with flexible asset interactions. The choice of curve should align with the project's goals, target market, and long-term sustainability plans.
Reserve Ratio: Lower ratios (e.g., 20%) create higher price sensitivity and potential returns but less stability; higher ratios (e.g., 80%) offer more price stability and liquidity but lower potential returns and faster reserve depletion; the optimal ratio balances these factors based on project goals and risk tolerance.
Fee Structure: If implementing a fee, design the mechanism to balance revenue generation for the project with maintaining attractive economics for token holders and liquidity providers. Consider factors such as fee percentage, fee distribution, and the potential for adjusting fees over time.
Front-Running Protection: Implement mechanisms like Batch Auctions to prevent or mitigate front-running attacks, which can be particularly problematic for token bonding curves.

resources.resource: Bancor’s Smart Tokens vs Token Bonding Curves (Simon de la Rouviere)
Tokens 2.0: Curved Token Bonding in Curation Markets (Simon de la Rouviere)
On Bonding Curves as Funding Mechanisms (Wilson Lau)
Exploring Bonding Curves: Differentiating Primary and Secondary Automated Market Makers (Bonding Curve Research Group)

example_details: Integrates additional mechanisms to address some of the limitations and risks of traditional bonding curves. It includes a reserve pool to stabilize the token price and a funding pool to support community projects. It also incorporates a vesting mechanism to prevent early speculation and a governance model to ensure that the funding is allocated to initiatives that benefit the community. The curve can be polynomial or another complex function, depending on the specific implementation.

Social platform that applies bonding curves to tokenize social influence. Each creator has a personal token governed by a polynomial bonding curve, precisely a quadratic "sum of squares" formula. These "key" tokens grant holders access to the creator's private group chat and content. The platform implements a 10% fee on all transactions, equally split between the creator and friend.tech. The bonding curve ensures continuous liquidity and incentivizes early participation, while the fee structure aligns the interests of creators, users, and the platform itself.

GHST is sold for DAI on a bonding curve gated to users who have been approved through a centralized KYC process. GHST is a currency token that users can spend on portals and wearables. Spent GHST is split between users via rarity farming, the developer team, and the community DAO, and a portion is burned, which increases the bonding curve price.

title: Token Curated Registry (TCR)
description: A registry that is curated by token holders who are incentivized to maintain its integrity.
details:
TCRs were initially proposed by Mike Goldin as a way to have a decentralized set of actors essentially curate a list. This could be any form of information — be it something subjective such as a grocery list, a list of “noteworthy projects,” or even a more enforceable registry such as an allowlist or blocklist for a forum.
Actions in this system involve nominating, voting, and challenging existing registry items, all controlled through token voting. The incentives and involved parties are structured as the following:
Self-interested curators (token holders) create a valuable list to increase the value of their voting power.
Candidates that wish to be curated into “important” lists would effectively buy or petition their way onto the registry.
Consumers desire a trustworthy north star for curated information.
There are also additional incentive systems that keep people from making bad decisions, such as a failed nomination slashing the bond put in place to make that nomination in the first place. In this case, token holders are incentivized to keep the information on the list as noteworthy and “valuable” as possible to keep the system running and their holdings worth something.
source: https://medium.com/@Obstropolos/party-on-tcr-party-af0035199b9

title: Token Gate
description: Restricting access to certain services, features or content based on token holdings.
details: This can be used with any variety of tokens (transferable, non-transferable, fungible, non-fungible) and combinations thereof. Additional constraints can also be included, such as the amount of time a token has been held.

title: Token Inflation
description: Issuing new supply of a token to to incentivize a particular set of behaviors.

title: Token Stream
description: Continuous transfer of tokens from a sender's account to a receiver's account.
details: The sender's account balance decreases at a specific rate per second, while the receiver's account balance increases at the same rate. This mechanism allows for smooth, real-time transactions and can be useful in various applications, such as subscription services, payroll systems, and time-based contracts.

title: Token Timelock
description: A mechanism that locks tokens for a set period of time to prevent them from being transferred or sold.

title: Token Vesting
description: A mechanism that releases tokens over a predetermined period, often used to incentivize team members or early investors.

title: Token-Weighted Voting
description: Assigning voting power based on the number of tokens held by each participant.

example_details:
In MakerDAO, the MKR token serves a dual purpose as both a governance token and an economic instrument subject to a "Buyback & Burn" mechanism.
Governance MKR token holders have the authority to vote on various aspects of the Maker system, including stability fee rates, collateral types, and system upgrades. This governance model allows decentralized control over the MakerDAO ecosystem.
Fee Capture through Buyback & Burn Upon paying down a collateralized debt position in DAI to retreive the underslying collateral, the user must also pay a 'stability fee.' This fee is converted into MKR tokens on the open market and then burned, effectively reducing the total supply. This aims to increase the value of remaining MKR tokens as a mechanism for MKR holders to capture network fees.

title: Tokenized Vault
description: Receipt tokens represent a claim on an underlying pool of tokens that grows with fees being generated.
details:
These can take many forms, such as:
xTokens, which represent a claim on growing pool of the underlying token that is automatically purchased with user fees.
Liquid staking derivatives like stETH and rETH which represent a claim on growing pool of ETH from validator rewards.
Liquidity Pool Tokens (LPTs) for AMM-based exchanges like Uniswap-v2, Balancer, and Curve, which represents claim on growing pool of user fees from swaps.
Share tokens in money markets like Compound (cTokens) or Aave (aTokens), which represent interest bearing version of the token
Share tokens in yield aggregators like Yearn (yTokens), which represent a share in the pool that receives the gains from the underlying strategy.

title: Transaction Fee
description: A fee charged for transactions that occur within a particular marketplace or ecosystem, such as a purchase of NFTs.

title: Tribute
description: A proposal to contribute funds, often in exchange for a native token. Funds are held in escrow until the proposal passes and are returned to the proposer if if fails.

title: Universal Basic Income (UBI)
description: Provides all participants in a network with a basic income.

title: Variable Rate Gradual Dutch Auction (VRGDA)
description: Novel token issuance mechanism designed for Art Gobblers and used in 0xMonaco that allows for the sale of tokens close to a custom schedule over time by raising prices when sales are ahead of schedule and lowering prices when sales are behind schedule.
details: The VRGDAs mechanism is a generalization of the GDA mechanism, and it provides both an overview of the mechanism and a highly optimized production-ready Solidity implementation of the core mechanism and several example schedules. The objective of VRGDAs is to issue NFTs on a particular schedule while maintaining a seamless user experience that would allow users to buy NFTs at any time without having to wait for a scheduled auction. The VRGDAs mechanism allows for arbitrary scheduling of NFT issuance as opposed to the uniform linear scheduling of standard GDAs. The implementation of VRGDAs provides a way to issue NFTs using nearly any schedule you would like while still allowing users to seamlessly buy them at any time, creating potential applications across NFTs on-chain gaming, DeFi, and beyond.

example_details:
Fully on-chain PvP word game
Place letters on an (infinite) grid to spell words
Each letter has a fluctuating price (VRGDA)
Make ETH by scoring points and when others play your letters

title: ve(3,3)
description: Variation of the veToken model that provides dilution protection and flexibility to token lockers.
details:
How it works:
This is designed to encourage users to lock their tokens, resulting in a more stable environment.

title: Verifiable Credential (VC)
description: A digital credential that can be used to verify the identity or qualifications of an individual or organization.

title: Veto
description: The ability of certain participants to reject a proposed action.
details:
Veto power is often used to prevent malicious or undesirable changes from being approved by the majority. It can enhance security and stability by adding an additional layer of scrutiny to proposed updates. However, it also comes with potential concerns, as a concentrated veto power could lead to centralization and decision-making biases.
Veto powers can often be used in the early stages of a system as part of progressive decentralization. In this case, a multisignature wallet of trusted actors can retain veto powers while a larger more decentralized group proposes changes. Veto powers can also be part of a more permanent setup where a separation of powers between different classes of actors is desired.

example_details: Proposed governance change that would give stETH holders the ability veto proposals submitted by LDO holders. The dual-governance setup allows stakers of ETH (the protocol's users) to block any adversarial change by LDO holders (the protocol's owners).

title: veToken
description: "Vote Escrowed" tokens are non-transferable tokens generated by locking up the original token. The longer tokens are locked, the more veToken are generated. veTokens usually represent a share of voting power and profits of a system.

title: Vickrey Auction
description: Bidders submit written bids without knowing the bid of the other people in the auction. The highest bidder wins but the price paid is the second-highest bid.

title: Vote Decay
description: Stake weighting that decays according to certain factors, such as automatically over time or from not participating in governance.
details: The stake could correspond to financial rewards, governance rights or utility, such as access to services or work opportunities.

title: Vote Delegation
description: Any address can delegate its voting rights to any other address, allowing them to vote on their behalf.
details:
Vote delegation can support transitive delegation or be one hop.
Vote delegation can also be topic-specific, where an address can delegate its voting rights on different types of decisions to different addresses.

title: Wait for Quiet Voting
description: Wait until voting has quited down before closing a vote.

resources.resource: Using “Wait for Quiet” voting in The DAO

title: Web of Trust (WoT)
description: Mechanism for establishing and managing trust relationships among entities in a peer-to-peer network based on the endorsements and validations of others within the network.
details:
In a Web of Trust, each participant (or node) can vouch for the trustworthiness of other nodes. Trust is not binary but rather exists on a spectrum, allowing for a nuanced representation of trust levels. The trustworthiness of a particular node is determined not just by the number of endorsements it receives but also by the trustworthiness of the endorsers themselves. This creates a network where trust propagates and evolves dynamically.
WoT borrows from social network theory, particularly the concept of transitive trust – the idea that trust can be extended through a network based on mutual connections. This is akin to how one person might trust a friend's friend in a social context. WoT also draws from decentralized authentication systems like PGP (Pretty Good Privacy), which employs bilateral digital signatures for secure communications. The idea of trust being derived from interconnected endorsements aligns with algorithms like PageRank, which determine the importance of a webpage based on the network of links.
Advantages & Applications
Rating System: WoT can be used for decentralized rating systems, where trustworthiness is dynamically scored based on peer reviews.
Identity Verification: It offers a framework for decentralized identity verification, reducing reliance on central authorities.
Currency/Universal Basic Income (UBI): In cryptocurrency or UBI systems, WoT can help in authenticating participants and preventing fraud.
Limitations & Risks
Sybil Attacks: The network is vulnerable to Sybil attacks, where an attacker creates multiple fake identities to gain disproportionate influence.
Complex Network Dynamics: The trust relationships can become complex and hard to manage as the network grows.
Trust Decay: Over time, trust endorsements might become outdated, leading to a decay in the accuracy of trust assessments.
Key Considerations
Balancing Trust and Scalability: Designers must balance the depth of trust relationships with the network's scalability.
Dynamic Trust Updates: Implement mechanisms for the continuous updating and reassessment of trust endorsements.
Mitigating Sybil Attacks: Establish protocols to detect and mitigate the influence of Sybil attacks.

example_details: A social identity network that utilizes WoT for creating a secure and scalable identity system.

title: Weighted Voting
description: A type of voting where voters can distribute voting points among different options, allowing them to indicate their level of preference.

example_details: DAO Drops was a retroactive funding experiment that enabled thousands of Ethereum users to influence the allocation of ecosystem funds through weighted voting.

title: Work Token
description: Service providers stake the network's native token to gain the opportunity to work for the network. The more tokens a provider stakes, the higher their chances of getting the next job, relative to the total tokens staked by all providers.
details:
Absent speculation, the token's price should increases as network usage grows. As the service demand increases, providers earn more revenue. With a fixed token supply, providers will logically pay more per token to access a growing income stream.
Work token systems typically include a penalty mechanism for workers who don't meet predefined performance standards.
They can also include delegated reward models where token-holders can delegate tokens to nodes in order to earn a share of rewards. Delegated rewards may or may not be subject to slashing if the delegated to node is slashed.
The set of active nodes may be unbounded, statically bounded, or dynamically bounded.

example_details:
Nodes stake LPT to receive transcoding work. The larger the amount of staked Livepeer Token (LPT), the more likely a node is to receive more transcoding work, which results in them earning more transcoding fees.
In addition to earning transcoding fees from users in ETH, nodes receive LPT tokens that are dynamically minted by the protocol based on the overall participation rate.
When the participation rate falls below 50% in a given round, LPT issuance increases by a small percentage and it decreases when the participation rate passes 50%.

title: xToken
description: Receipt token that earns yield based on profit-share from fees.
details: The original token is staked in exchange for shares in the profit pool, referred to as "xTokens". A portion of the system's revenues are used to buy the underlying Token and route it to the profit pool, acting as a virtual buyback mechanism to share profits with stakers. The ratio of xToken to Token therefore goes up over time.

title: Yield Delegation
description: Pooling tokens in order to donate the yield to a third-party.
